151207697.review:
Utterly brilliant VR game, if you have a good headset and system, it's like "being there".

No, not in some "it's game, but you're there, in that same 3D" like it's "Lawnmower Man" from the 90s.

NO, no, no, no. The rendering, the depth perception, the 3D implementation is more like being in a Star Trek TNG Holodeck. It's the "3D graphics" but they look not 10, or 15, or 20, but 100 better, more organic. The detail of the textures comes out incredibly strong, noticing all the bells/whistles, small details, like rivets in the armor, the glossi-ness of the eyes, the remarkable iridescent of soul gems, or any gem you pick up and hold up for a closer look.

It's like being at Disneyland on some cool ride with animatronics, with all the sights/sounds perfectly crafted, but imagine if those Imagination animatronics had RPG-NPC-AI and get up and walk around doing whatever. Crazy good.

Most Skyrim SE mods work great (not all though and not all work at all). Just be sure to check for specific "VR" versions first. If it doesn't exist, then it's a dice-roll if it will work or not. Surprisingly though, many do, but do that due diligence first or your risk losing time when the game tries to load and crashes tons, trying to figure out which mod or mods are causing the problems. Ugh.

You see everything in a "true 3D" like you would see reality. Not some "flat 360-degree IMAX-like" version.
Like I said, it's like you're there.

Good mods are the one that lets you grab/pick up everything (including NPCs) or your gestures to easily interact with NPCs and they react (remember the 6-foot rule, if you grab/bump them too much they will aggro all "WTF BRO!") and the mod that renders your entire body (Skyrim VR just shows your wrists/hands, ugh). So whatever out you put on, you're literally wearing it and can look down at see yourself wearing it and all. Insane.

Enhanced blood and other type mods are cool. It's crazy swinging your weapons to pummel an enemy and seeing your weapon, hands, armor, and all covered in blood lol. Also, crazy to travel to here/there, it's like "oh wow, next I really need to go up the mountain right over there yonder to see the Greybeards?"

It's a whoooole other, different experience than the normal Skyrim game.

Again, it's not "you're there but "inside" and the graphics look the same".

Noooo, the graphics are 100x better, the depth perception and all renders it on such a level no screenshot or video can ever do it justice. They're out there but it looks nothing like that crap, it's 100X better and "real". Extremely immersive. You feel like you are "There-there"!

What a bummer, while I paid full price, the thing goes on sale dropping down from $60 to $15. Press F!!!!

Even so, the entertainment value IMO, the full price is justified.
That said, however, I have a pretty good, modern machine, and the Quest 3 that just came out a month ago which is higher quality than Quest 2 and others. For me, the game runs silky smooth, flawless, NO stutters/lag or anything (I don't link via wifi but to my system via wire so it renders off my system, not so much the VR itself).

If anyone has never tried VR before but loves Skryim and goes to play this with a good setup and decent VR, will crap their pants. I can't imagine going back to play normal Skyrim without itching all "OK but what if THIS was VR?" then seeing how most the mods I use work with VR, so then just go into the VR.

Also fun, the dual-equip "Shock" and go "POWER! UNLIIIMITED POWER!" at some fool that starts crap with me. Literally, lifting my hands for realz and going all dark lord of the Sith on a foe running at me with an axe, and I'm all "Well, I know magic, beeeoch!" and blast them.

The grabbing mod is great too, whereas in the game NPCs can be dumb and go into traps and get rekt, whereas I can walk up and grab them and pull out of danger with one hand, while healing them with my other hand. Then they go "Thank you!".
Incredible. The immersion is just insane.

151144912.review:
Not ready out of the box; Skyrim VR ships not only with an awful control scheme, but with multiple performance issues regarding framerate, physics, and just general stability. Stabilizing it is NOT the same as stabilizing Skyrim SE, as you may find SteamVR itself actually tanks performance itself and need to use OpenComposite, which requires a lot more set up and unfortunately lists Skyrim VR as broken.

I must repeat, this is NOT the charming bugginess of your average Bethesda game, the six hours I apparently spent with the game so far was not spent playing it; I was trying to get it to run without freezing.

I will do my best to get the game to function, as I can't return it at this point, and I'll hopefully get it running and maybe even have fun with it, since I've been looking forward to being able to afford it for months-- but I definitely would not say the game is worth $60. Right now, it isn't even worth the $16 I paid.

Games should be playable as soon as you get them installed. Skyrim VR is not.

149828598.review:
[h1] A Legendary VR Experience That Reinvents Skyrim! [/h1]
[h2] Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5) [/h2]



Skyrim VR is an absolute masterpiece that seamlessly transports players into the breathtaking world of Tamriel like never before. As an avid fan of the original game, I was skeptical about how well the VR adaptation would translate, but I'm thrilled to say that it has exceeded my wildest expectations.

The first thing that struck me was the sheer scale and beauty of the virtual world. From snow-capped mountains to lush forests, every location is stunningly recreated with incredible attention to detail. I found myself lost for hours just exploring every nook and cranny, encountering familiar characters and stumbling upon hidden treasures. The level of immersion here is off the charts!

Combat has also been reimagined for VR, providing an unparalleled level of engagement. Using hand movements to wield swords, bows, and spells feels incredibly intuitive and natural. The intense rush of battle is enhanced tenfold when you're physically dodging incoming attacks or unleashing a devastating power shout with a simple gesture. The sheer joy of becoming your Dragonborn character is unmatched in any other VR game.

Additionally, the game's extensive content and replayability factor remain intact in the VR adaptation. The countless quests, factions, and choices ensure that no two playthroughs are ever the same. The inclusion of all Skyrim's DLCs only adds to the longevity of this title, providing endless hours of adventure and excitement.

One aspect that surprised me is the smooth performance and comfort factor. Skyrim VR has been optimized very well, reducing motion sickness and providing customizable comfort options for players sensitive to locomotion in VR. This is a major improvement compared to some other VR titles that often struggle in this regard.

Another feature worth mentioning is the active modding community, allowing players to further enhance their experience.  



[b] -My favorite drinking buddy! Let's get some mead. [/b]

The port [i]is[/i] a bit underwhelming, though it's pretty playable as is. The only really broken part I encountered was riding flying dragons, which has the player and dragon rotating out of sync! Pretty small part of the game though. If you have the original game, then yes, its is a bit steep, and you should wait for a sale. I'm one of the small number of people who had never played the game flatscreen, so buying it was a no-brainer for me.

Where Skyrim VR really comes into its own is with the use of mods. As others have already said: with mods SkyrimVR feels more like a modern VR title and is a whole lot of fun.

I've modded the game myself, but if you're in a hurry, pick up one of the Wabbajack VR mod lists. For those that don't know, Wabbajack is a mod downloader and installer that literally does the whole thing for you. I decided to give 'Skyrim VR Minimalistic Overhaul' a go, and am very impressed. It's available in plain and NSFW... Just google it.

146141219.review:
Skyrim VR is fantastic, more on that later. But for now, some words of warning. If you're using the Index controllers you [b][i] will [/i][/b] need to use some mods. It literally doesn't work without the VRIK mod and the keybinding alterations it offers as you can't navigate menus. I personally took 10 hours of my playtime just to problem solve what was wrong, so if you're seeing this review that's what's wrong. Also don't launch up the game with all the 2K texture mods imaginable, but add them gradually as you test your PC's limits. Half of my problem solving time was trying to figure out why the game was running on 2 FPS. Well, that was the issue. Just go fully vanilla until you get out of Helgen, and then meddle with mods. Just to make sure that if you have any problems with the game it's with the mods, not the game.

Now for the good stuff. Skyrim VR is everything you can imagine, and a little bit more. Along with VRIK that also gives you a full body I highly recommend getting HIGGS. It enables object interaction so your hand doesn't go through everything you touch, and you can also pick items up and throw them at people. And if you're so inclined, certain "physics" are supported for hand interactions as well, just saying. And if you thought using the bow in the original game was fun, in VR it's even more so. Not only can you aim anywhere you want to, say behind a tree or do a trickshot behind your back, you can also rapid fire arrows. Your only limitation is your feeble arms. It's extremely satisfying. Pair that with something like locational damage and you've got yourself a playstyle you can't live without.

Combat of course is a lot better in this as well, though swords don't actually go through people as much as I would've wanted to, but I'm sure there's a mod out there to fix it. Maces, however, are really good. If you've got the right mods to support the physics (Like PLANCK) you can just use a mace to swing at someone's head and send them flying. Then after doing that, you can pick up the body and throw it even further. Not that there's any need to do that, of course. Other weapons are a little underwhelming like I mentioned before. Your dagger will just behave like a wooden club as much as it has in every other version of Skyrim.

Since this is just a port of the original Skyrim, mods that worked in Special Edition will work in this one as well. Just be informed that the Unofficial Patch is not supported in this version so importing the entire load order from SE will not go well, so it's best to check them first. There's also a lot of VR-specific mods, like the ones I've listed previously, so even if you've beaten the game many, many times before, there's still something new to be had with the VR version.

One thing that I immediately noticed was the scale, how absurdly massive everything is. That door to Bleakfalls Barrow could be opened to let a mammoth through, and when you're looking at mountains you're actually looking up. This is also relevant when you're trying to scale a mountain with a horse because your neck will be snapped at roughly 85 degrees just so see where you're going. And the paths especially look steep as all hell, and it's not something you can really notice in the desktop versions. How anyone's supposed to lug carriage up them is beyond me, but I digress.

In conclusion, the game really doesn't break new ground. The base game is quite literally just a camera replacement for the VR headset. But what it does do is give a new perspective, more ways to use what you already had. But at its very core, it's just the same old Skyrim. And like the original Skyrim, it's best to use at least [i] some [/i] mods. One thing I'd like to mention at the end here is that you can import all your saves from Skyrim SE as well Skyrim to this and it will work without an issue, you just can't export them back to those versions without guarantee.

This is the best game in VR once properly modded (sorry, HL:A), and properly modded it's maybe my favorite game of all time. 

When I first modded the game, I used Aerowynx's guide, which took a lot of time and effort to get everything properly set up and running well. It also depended on some files that are no longer available, and is functionally obsolete. Got a new computer recently, and had no idea how to preserve everything. 

So I went with the FUS Wabbajack (my first time using Wabbajack), which took a mere two hours to completely install, plus $6 for one month of a Nexus Premium account that I immediately canceled. And running the FUS ROH configuration the game is absolutely perfect. At first, I was frustrated that my saved games depended on mods I no longer had, so I had to start all over again. But the FUS ROH mods actually made it a joy rather than a chore to begin again, and I was surprised at all the quests I still hadn't experienced.

(If all this Wabbajack and FUS stuff is confusing to you, visit the SkyrimVR subreddit.)

After goofing around (I started the Brotherhood quest, but it took a turn I didn't want my character to follow) some, I headed off to Winterhold College -- deciding on a Destruction Mage build again, and remembering that becoming the Arch Mage scores you some items that will last you throughout the game and some cool digs. 

Yes, you have to mod this game to make it really great. But once you do, it's REALLY great. And with the FUS Wabbajack it's now stupid-easy to get the best set of mods possible up and running.

144462407.review:
First off, silly first impressions:

1. As a not-very-tall person of 5'5", I feel like I'm either the height of a 10 year old kid, or I'm floating 30 cm above the ground. Everyone in this world is like 2 metres tall. It's pretty sad for people like me :(

2. I swear the person who came up with the default control scheme for this game used a random generator to assign controls. Whoever decided that pressing forward on your right controller would make you jump instead of pressing A, grabbing made you go back, instead of pressing B; B and Y took you left and right in menus, instead of pressing the trigger buttons; and both rotating your left hand and rotating the hat switch made you change the direction you were walking, causing you to walk like a drunkard everywhere... must have been taking some serious drugs that day. I'm sure this can be fixed in settings, gad damn.


Next up, why I don't recommend this game:

This really should be a feature or a DLC rather than a whole new game. It's a pretty basic port where even most mods for the original Skyrim still work with it. Definitely not worth the full price at least.
It'a also annoying because I can't play with the accounts I have on my regular Skyrim in VR when I want. I either have to make an account that's 100% VR or 100% desktop. VR tends to be an effort to set up and I'd rather play desktop on some days, and sometimes I want to have an immersive experience and I play in VR mode. Having these as completely separate games prevents me from doing that with one playthrough. It's quite disappointing. 
There's also the fact that Skyrim was originally meant to be played on desktop, and there's a lot of things in VR that don't work very well, such as weapon handling (how-fast-can-you-move-your-wrist-back-and-forth weapon speeds) plus some other bugs that come with this being a very basic port. 
If you have a VR headset and you're wondering whether you should buy this version of the desktop version, I'll send you to the desktop version without second thoughts. If you already have Skyrim and you want a new experience with the game in VR, yeah, sure you can get this if you want, if you don't mind that you'll have to start over with a new playthrough, and the game is still basically exactly the same as the desktop version, only a bit worse and in VR, and it costs extra money.

143714651.review:
The game is simply awful. I expected mechanics like Blade and Sorcery, with gravity for the weapons, the ability to grip a weapon with two hands. Instead what I got was weightless weapons that you can just flick around and instantly kill opponents, even when enabling all of the "realism" settings. This is an issue that does not exist in the non-vr version of TES V, since the heavier weapons take longer to swing, so I'd much rather play that version of the game. It's literally just a port of the classic Skyrim, with removed weapons physics. If you are playing Skyrim for the first time, this may be the better version to do it on, just install some mods for weapons gravity (I think they exist, I didn't even check). The whole point of playing Skyrim is the immersion, and with that one aspect of weapons gravity, this version could be better than the original.

Waiting for my refund soon, as I don't want Bethesda to receive my 20$ for this lazy port after I've purchased Skyrim for the Xbox 360, one, and my Steam account.

Brief summary of pros and cons:

Pros:
More immersive than the original Skyrim but requires mods for it.
Nice bow and arrow shooting
May be a nice introduction for first-time vr players in general.

Cons:
Without mods, weightless weapon physics which results in a spamfest.
With mods, achievements will be disabled. (as a player who likes completionism every now and then, this is a big deal for me)

143498387.review:
I would recommend this game ONLY on the condition that you have the willpower and resolve to spend a good few hours modding it first. I'm serious. If you're not up to modding, or don't have the space on your computer for extra stuff, or feel like it's going to ruin the experience, do NOT buy this. Standard Skyrim VR is straight up Skyrim Special Edition, all the bugs included. There is barely ANY work put into porting it into a VR game, with maybe the only notable exception being the Eagle Eye ability in the archery skill tree. It looks terrible and has none of the interactive qualities that you will likely be expecting if you've played, say, literally any other VR game in the past five years. I'm not kidding; if you don't want to mod it don't buy it at all. 

That being said: there are many guides out there to make it look and feel more like a modern VR game. I failed trying to make this game feel enjoyable once and gave up for 6 months before finding a guide I enjoyed. only after following that guide and getting ~130 mods (MANY for updated visuals, and then a good number to make the game... feel like a VR game and not a horrible port of a 2011 game) am I really enjoying it. I will link the guide I've followed below. I would also recommend a companion app available on Steam called Natural Locomotion, which lets you swing your arms (or feet, if you want to go through the setup) in order to walk through the world.

that being said, I've never actually beat standard Skyrim before-- I would just get bored and back out after a good few levels. playing in VR is so much more immersive and enthralling. I'm always excited to get back into the world and see what it has to hold and what there is to discover. I have the benefit of not having played the original in so long I literally remembered almost nothing, so the experience is not only refreshed by being in VR, but it is also actually new to me. The worldbuilding was good when it came out and really holds up. Walking around the world in roomscale is comparable to (and in my opinion better than) walking around as Link in Breath of the Wild-- there's always something for you to discover along the way to your destination, and a hundred ways to approach any problem (though, just like has always been the case, sneaky archery is usually the easiest).

I honestly see myself finishing the game like this. I cannot emphasize enough how much credit should go to the many, many people that have put timeless hours into modding this game to make it enjoyable.

the mod list I most closely followed (with a few tweaks according to my taste and needs): 
https://www.reddit.com/r/skyrimvr/comments/8riiqk/and_refined_my_texture_and_modding_guide_140/

A comprehensive guide to modding Skyrim VR, in which you can find about a million resources and recommended mods and plugins: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qbh7GE30xLyso7MA6u3xpNJNdL5r2V2WP8SjZ4VpHLQ/edit

141559162.review:
Skyrim VR is an alright VR port of what is overall a good Open World RPG. I feel every gamer should at some point escape Helgen, if for no other reason than because of how iconic the opening of this game is. If you have never played Skyrim, this is a great way to first experience it. You will be blown away by the absurd amount of things to be done in this game, but that's really where the biggest issue lies.

The issue is that Skyrim is an absolutely massive game with hundreds if not thousands of hours of content, and if you try to complete all of it, you will almost certainly get bored of the general feel of the game first. Typically, multiplayer would be a good solution to this boredom, but Skyrim doesn't have multiplayer. You are eternally alone in this game, and unlike other single-player games I've played, I often felt painfully alone when in Skyrim. Fun can certainly be had nonetheless, but it's likely going to decrease exponentially for the longer you play. It's for that reason that I promptly uninstalled the game once I had gotten every achievement.

I do still recommend the game, but not as heavily as I would recommend another single-player story-based VR game such as Budget Cuts or Half-Life: Alyx. Those games left me wanting more, but Skyrim VR does not.

141386179.review:
Skyrim VR is a stunning and immersive way to experience this epic fantasy world! Its amazing to be able to explore this vast and beautiful landscape of Skyrim in virtual reality!

However its not perfect at all. The native game suffers from some graphical downgrades and performance issues, the combat can also feel clumsy and imprecise and the character models and animations look outdated and awkward in VR. Therefor... Mods are a must!

Mods will drastically improve the game play and visual quality. They dramatically enhance the graphics, lighting, textures, sounds, UI, combat, and more. They can also add new features, quests, items, and characters to the game. Mods can make Skyrim VR look and feel like a whole new game, and they are EASY to INSTALL. You can Find plenty of Youtube Video recommending all sorts of Mods and walk-throughs on how to install them.

Modded Skyrim VR is a fantastic game that deserves to be played in virtual reality. You should definitely give it a try! 10/10

141271388.review:
DISCLAIMER:

Ok so I have minimal play time. But I still feel like I can say this. The game is amazing MODDED vanilla is trash.  A lot of time you will spend is going to be modding for the first 1-3 days so you got to have determination to mod and a lot of times you may screw up and have to either A. Test to see which mod is crashing you or B. Restart the entire list SO ALWAYS keep track of what mods you download when and only download a select few at a time so that way you can seed out the ones that break the game easier. You will probably never stop modding this game I have about 100 but there's people with over 400 and even then if you reach that point you may still switch things up and replace a few or even add more. The good news is however when you do reach a point where you are satisfied for the most part the new mods you add will only be like 1 or 2 cool armor sets maybe as opposed to 50 different graphical enhancements that took 4 hours to download (Speaking from experience) but if you can endure the long hours of sitting there doing nothing and babysitting your PC (I watched videos to entertain me that helped a lot) it will all be worth it modded it has to be one of the most cool and beautiful VR experiences out there. Me personally it's been about a day and a half of constant modding and testing and I am getting to a point where the game is beautiful and has all the VR essentials so it may take less then 2 days but 2 days is about average modding time I'd say. You can even create a mod collection idk if you can set those to private but what I do is just write them down and back them up so I don't have to wait so long to download it all again. Now one more thing I HIGHLY RECOMMEND it's called cherry picking look for high endorsed collections and sort through the mods find which ones you like don't download them all just get the ones that seem appealing to you. A GREAT START IS this guy named Habbie you can search Habbie Skyrim VR online find his most recent video go to the description and download all the mods he has because he has the bare minimum mods to make it actually playable then branch out and install your own mods. I would also recommend this game on sale although great modded 60$ for a game modders had to fix is super scummy so buy it on sale. Now that's just the disclaimer onto gameplay review (WITH MODS NOT VANILLA)

Gameplay review (WITH MODS):

The game is awesome I mean getting to slice my enemies with a heavy 2 handed axe pretty sweet. The things you can do to NPCS is quite immersive there is tons of roleplaying options. For example you could be a cannibal or a werewolf and just eat people and actually bend down to eat them or you could sneak into people's houses and hold knifes to their throats and kill them that way or be a vampire and actually sink your teeth in sucking the blood from them. And without mods the graphics are good but with the graphical mod lineup I have stunning when I'm tired and sweaty from walking around I sit down and enjoy the night sky look at all the stars and the moon. Maybe I look to the mountains in the distant see how they howl. Sometimes I will travel through a harsh blizzard in search of a way out or shelter. Or a dark cavern full of mysteries and dangerous traps. I can go assassins creed style and kill a villager pick their body up hoist it over my shoulder and drop them in some shrubs. The possibilities are endless for RP you can be whatever you want or do whatever you want. I love it stunning game and a wonderful VR experience (IF MODDED) and like I said in the disclaimer you gotta be ready to heavily mod it or you will be disappointed.

Some of these reviewers are feeling more generous than I am. Sure, you can fix this pile of poop and make it pretty nice(but not bug free) with mods. But the modders deserve that credit. Bethesda does not. This is the laziest imaginable VR port ever. Most of the controls were ported over from Skyrim special edition, other than the hand motion based combat that makes you feel like a little girl hitting a frog with a stick(there are combat mods for this). Same engine was ported over too, only without many of the bug fixes. Instead of adapting the engine and graphics to VR, they simply seriously reduced the detail and the view distance. And I know with an AMD processor and Windows 10 that the game crashes often within five minutes without the unofficial patch. This game is the epitome of why big studios should be hanging their heads in shame. I literally tried to figure out anyway they could have made this any lazier and more uninspired and I am coming up empty.

Buy it at the deepest discount you possibly can. Bethesda does not deserve any compensation for this. I wish I could give my money to the modding community that made this game a very worthwhile experience instead(I did buy a nexus mods subscription). But word of warning, by the time you have it modded to be a good experience, the system requirements increase exponentially. I have had to do a fair bit of optimization on my system in order to get this all running smoothly. But it is now the best open world game on VR currently. Recommended, but with a serious disclaimer: The vanilla experience is one of the laziest VR implementations I've ever played and is nearly unplayable. Every single person at Bethesda involved with this release should be deeply ashamed on a personal and professional level for both the obvious contempt they have for their customers, and for the lack of passion they have for their craft. It's a staggering display of incompetence and apathy.

However, with the current mods available at time of writing this review, the gameplay and VR interactions can be fixed and fully transformed into what it should have been and puts it on par with other "real" VR games, which is nearly a miracle given the vanilla state of things. With the correct overhaul mods (HIGGS, VRIK, PLANCK are the big three, but there are a dozen others that I highly recommend and that all coalesce to further fix the experience) it becomes worth a buy, but only at the [i]deepest possible discount[/i] to ensure Bethesda is rewarded as little as possible for what they've done here.

That aside, it's exactly what you think it is. It's Skyrim, but in VR. [b]With the appropriate mods[/b], you will be able to engage in fairly good physical combat, cast spells with gestures, pet dogs, pick up and throw/manipulate items, and so forth. Of course, there are also some great sights to see that look extra impressive or scary in VR. There's fun to be had here as long as you aren't already too burned out on flat Skyrim. As the VR version is built off of Skyrim SE, most SE-compatible mods also seem to work with it (Lorkhan, etc).

137844235.review:
Pretty much any game developer can tell you that making a title for virtual reality isn't as simple as "hitting the VR button." A lot of work goes into making a VR title—especially one worth actually playing. That makes it all the more annoying that it really does feel like Bethesda just hit the "make it VR" button when porting The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition to VR. Aside from half-baked hand tracking and a custom starting area, very little care was put into making Skyrim an interesting VR game. While it's neat to explore Tamriel in a more immersive way, the game lacks the physicality that VR promises. There's very little in the way of physics interactions—your hands barely interact with the environment, phasing through people and items. Without collision, melee combat feels like whiffing at the air. Congratulations, you're playing Skyrim again, but this time, you're doing it standing up. To add insult to injury, players are expected to purchase this rush-job separately from the desktop version of Special Edition—which I still don't even own. If they were going to put so little effort into it, it should have been a free update to Special Edition and not a full-price standalone purchase.

Not all is lost, though. I had quite a good time playing Skyrim in virtual reality, but that's despite Bethesda—not thanks to them. If you're willing to spend half a day modding the game and learning how to correctly apply confusing shit like DynDOLOD, Skyrim VR is more than just a salvageable experience—it's one worth getting into. The Elder Scrolls fan community has done an amazing job of making this port worth playing. With a handy guide and a bit of patience on the player's part, it's possible to make the world of Tamriel a beautiful, jaw-dropping experience worth exploring for the visuals alone. The combat and gameplay... well, it's still Skyrim. That said, I feel like the notoriously same-y combat is made a bit more interesting when the swings of your sword, the drawing of your bow, and the casting of your spells are done with your own hands' movements. There's an additional layer of immersion there that makes the combat feel more worthwhile than the one-button-mashing of the desktop version. If you have a headset, an attachment to Skyrim, and some time to burn, I think it's worth trying out the game after modding it. Just... don't buy it. Bethesda could do without the encouragement.

137528612.review:
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR is a stunning and immersive virtual reality version of the classic open-world action role-playing game. Developed by Bethesda Game Studios, the game takes place in the world of Tamriel, where players take on the role of the Dragonborn, a hero with the power to slay dragons and save the land from a looming threat.

One of the game's standout features is its massive and immersive world, which is brought to life like never before in virtual reality. Players can explore the world of Tamriel in stunning detail, with every environment, character, and creature rendered in 3D. The game's world is vast and diverse, with a range of different regions to explore, each with its own unique landscape and culture. The game's attention to detail and world-building is unparalleled, and players will find themselves completely immersed in the game's world.

The gameplay is also exceptional, with a range of skills and abilities to customize and upgrade, as well as a deep and engaging combat system that rewards strategy and skill. The game's magic system is particularly impressive, offering players a range of spells and abilities to use in combat and exploration.

The VR implementation is outstanding, with intuitive controls and an immersive sense of presence that puts players right in the middle of the action. Players can use hand movements to interact with the world, cast spells, and swing weapons, making for a truly immersive experience.

The game also offers a deep and engaging story, with a range of memorable characters and choices that affect the game's narrative and outcome. The game's storytelling is further enhanced by its excellent writing and voice acting, making it a truly immersive experience.

Overall, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR is a stunning and immersive virtual reality experience that takes a classic game to new heights. Whether you're a fan of the genre or new to the world of action RPGs, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR is a game that is definitely worth playing for the sense of immersion and wonder it provides.

137304016.review: The story and lore of this game (and many other games by Bethesda ) is fantastic and amazing. These games always make me happy with how much story there is. But, this story is unfortunately ruined by the game's mechanics. The whole point of VR is to actually be there-in this fantasy world-not on a 2d screen. Skyrim VR lacks this aspect largely. For example, you cannot interact with objects or npcs. No grabbing or collision, just a button to pick it up and store in your inventory. Some might say that mods make up this game-that mods will make up for what this game is lacking. Though, this mainly comes from people who have massively expensive computers and are able to run the mods needed for the game to be bearable (most modlists are 300+ mods)(I am somewhat biased in saying this). Of course, I have tried to mod the game to make it work. Unfortunately my hard work was for nothing because even after spending 5+ hours (downloading mod manager, waiting 3 hours to install, getting rid of mod conflicts, manually installing more mods) my computer was unsuccessful in running the game smoothly. Everything was choppy and really glitchy. (only 1 example)Every time I would snap turn the game would glitch out and look weird. I know that this is a result of my lack of understanding that I cannot run this many mods on my computer and installing the mods anyway, but was still devastating to find out nevertheless (I did not give up right away, I tried many programs to run the game smoothly and other things but this would take way too much time to explain, so I will spare you the details). Skyrim Vr will be a fantastic experience to people who have the computer and patience to mod, but unfortunately not many people have this, and if you do it will still be difficult. Overall, I would advise you to not play this game.

136977056.review:
This game is 5/5 with mods. Without? I have no idea, and don't care to try. I've heard too many horror stories of game-breaking bugs and whatnot because Bethesda didn't really bother to make a complete VR experience when they shipped the game. 

I have an Oculus Quest 2, and the ability to stream this game from my mid-tier computer with Air Link is incredible. I've played a solid amount of hours so far, and every time I hop in, I end of spending an inordinate amount of time just wandering the landscape collecting resources and talking to the citizens instead of completing quests.  Being completely immersed in the game makes you want to stop and savor each town or encounter.

That complete immersion wouldn't be possible without a lot of incredible mods created by a dedicated modding community. To the devs who have continued to support the VR experience for the last few years; thank you. Without you, the graphics would probably look horrendous, I wouldn't be able to draw and sheathe weapons off my virtualized body, use epic magic without needing to do a bunch of "menuing", and there would be far more immersion-breaking bugs present.

If you're looking to get into modding the game, there are some great downloadable modlists from Wabbajack (search it) that are relatively easy to set up, so you can launch the game quickly and dive in to experience things for yourself.

135393584.review:
Skyrim VR   es la versión en realidad virtual del icónico juego de rol y acción desarrollado por Bethesda Game Studios. Lanzado en 2018, este título permite a los jugadores sumergirse en el vasto mundo de Skyrim de una manera completamente nueva e inmersiva.

La jugabilidad de Skyrim VR es muy similar a la del juego original, pero con algunas modificaciones y ajustes para adaptarse a la experiencia de realidad virtual. Los jugadores pueden elegir entre varias clases de personajes y aventurarse en un vasto mundo lleno de misiones, combates y criaturas míticas. La mecánica de lucha ha sido actualizada para ser más fluida y natural en VR, lo que significa que los jugadores pueden blandir su espada, arco o hechizo con precisión y habilidad.

La experiencia de realidad virtual en Skyrim VR es impresionante. Los jugadores pueden explorar el mundo de Skyrim en una escala completamente nueva, sintiéndose realmente como si estuvieran en el juego. Los gráficos y la inmersión son impresionantes, y la sensación de estar en el mundo de Skyrim es única y emocionante.

La banda sonora del juego también es impresionante, con una música evocadora y una narrativa emocionante que lleva a los jugadores a través de una historia épica. El sonido de los efectos especiales es impresionante y contribuye a crear una atmósfera envolvente y emocionante.

En conclusión, Skyrim VR es una experiencia impresionante que permite a los jugadores sumergirse en un mundo fantástico de una manera completamente nueva. Con gráficos impresionantes, jugabilidad fluida, sonido envolvente y una experiencia de realidad virtual emocionante, este juego es un excelente ejemplo de cómo la realidad virtual puede mejorar una experiencia de juego ya clásica. Para los fans de Skyrim y de los juegos de realidad virtual, este título es una opción imprescindible.

135198367.review:
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR is an immersive and expansive role-playing game developed by Bethesda Game Studios and released for virtual reality platforms in 2018. The game is a fully-featured version of the original Skyrim game, with added features and enhancements designed specifically for virtual reality gameplay.

One of the biggest advantages of Skyrim VR is the immersive gameplay experience that it provides. Players can explore the vast and detailed world of Tamriel, encountering creatures and characters along the way. The game's VR implementation allows players to physically move around and interact with the game's world, making it feel more real and engaging.

Another standout feature of Skyrim VR is the game's combat system, which has been optimized for virtual reality gameplay. Players can use motion controls to attack enemies with swords, shields, and other weapons, adding a level of physicality to combat that is absent in traditional Skyrim gameplay.

In addition to the core game, Skyrim VR also includes several features and enhancements that are exclusive to virtual reality gameplay. For example, the game includes a new motion control interface that allows players to navigate menus and inventory screens using hand gestures, as well as a new teleportation system that allows players to move around the game world more easily.

While Skyrim VR is a great game, there are some drawbacks to the VR implementation. The game's graphics are not as detailed as the original Skyrim game, and some players may experience motion sickness or other discomfort while playing for extended periods of time. Additionally, the game requires a high-end VR headset and a powerful computer to run smoothly, which may make it inaccessible to some players.

Overall, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR is a fantastic game that offers an immersive and engaging role-playing experience. The game's optimized combat system, motion control interface, and new teleportation system make it a standout title in the VR space. While it may not be for everyone, those who are willing to invest in the necessary hardware and overcome any potential discomfort will find a rewarding and memorable experience in Skyrim VR.

134554085.review:
Skyrim VR es una adaptación del famoso juego de rol de Bethesda, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, para la realidad virtual. El juego fue lanzado en 2018 y prometía ser una experiencia impresionante de realidad virtual. Sin embargo, la adaptación inicial del juego fue criticada por muchos jugadores por tener muchos problemas de rendimiento, controles incómodos y una falta de inmersión.

A pesar de los problemas iniciales, los mods y la comunidad de Skyrim VR han transformado el juego en una experiencia increíblemente inmersiva. Los mods permiten a los jugadores personalizar el juego y solucionar muchos de los problemas que existían en la versión original. La comunidad ha creado numerosos mods que mejoran la jugabilidad, añaden nuevas funciones y hacen que el juego se sienta más realista.

Algunos de los cambios más notables incluyen la adición de un cuerpo completo o el control de objetos a distancia, lo que hace que la jugabilidad sea mucho más intuitiva. También hay mods que mejoran la calidad visual del juego, añaden nuevas características de combate y amplían el mundo del juego con nuevos paisajes y lugares para explorar.

En general, aunque la adaptación inicial de Skyrim VR fue criticada por muchos jugadores, la comunidad y los mods han transformado el juego en una de las mejores experiencias de realidad virtual disponibles actualmente. Skyrim VR es un ejemplo de cómo la comunidad de jugadores puede mejorar significativamente un juego y hacer que una adaptación inicialmente mala se convierta en una experiencia increíblemente satisfactoria.

133694909.review:
If a neutral review was an option I would use that instead, but here we are. For the tl;dr, skip to the Conclusion at the bottom.

[h1]Same Skyrim, New Tricks:[/h1]

First let’s talk about what VR brings to the table in a game like Skyrim. Going from seeing Skyrim through a monitor to Skyrim through VR goggles adds a handful of truly marvelous perks, primarily immersion. The ability to experience the game world at a 1:1 scale is remarkably engaging, even if you’ve played through the game a handful of times already. Enemies present a heightened sense of threat in VR that they simply can’t when they’re on a 2D screen, casting magic using your real-world hands gives a feeling of power, and walking around the environments makes you appreciate the sheer size of them at a new level. So then VR is exclusively a good thing for Skyrim, right? Not quite.

Skyrim is a game originally from 2011, and the Special Edition release is from 2016. Both games certainly looked somewhere between good to decent when they were released, and with mods you can improve the look of each even further. By today’s standards or even 2018 standards when Skyrim VR was released, the graphics just don’t hold up and they shouldn’t be expected to. Unfortunately, Skyrim VR uses the same graphics as the 2016 Special Edition release meaning the extra immersion VR provides dramatically reduces the effective visual quality of many environments. Some issues you’ll likely notice include extra blocky objects and dated textures. Water appears chunky and jagged, plants look like a piece of plastic with a flower painted on, and the lighting makes views that should be scenic masterpieces look fairly plain. Bethesda’s choice to not upgrade the visuals of the game before moving it to VR is a significant hit to the quality of the game right away.

These graphical issues are not helped by gameplay quirks born from yanking a game from desktop to VR. Many HUD elements are placed at the very edge of your vision making them squirrely to find the heat of combat and the menu systems are clearly best navigated with a traditional gamepad or keyboard rather than a vr pointer. Items and corpses can’t be moved around in the world like they can be in any of the desktop releases, and your character has no physical representation in the world except for a set of rigid, unsightly VR hands. NPCs, enemies, props, and traps can all push you around the environment against your will which is a real problem for folks prone to motion sickness. Thankfully, [b]some[/b] of these issues can be fixed by modding.

[h1]Modding Skyrim VR:[/h1]

Unless it's your very first time playing the game, Skyrim is widely considered at its best when stuffed to the gills with mods. Skyrim mods make the gameplay less buggy, the graphics prettier, the frame rate more consistent, the interface more helpful, the enemies more engaging, the weapons and armor more varied, the spells more useful, the skills more interesting, and even add whole new areas to the game if you like. This isn't to say that playing Skyrim isn't good or isn't fun [b]without[/b] mods, but after you play your first 20 or 30 hours of vanilla Skyrim you'll probably be thinking "huh I wish the two handed combat felt more impactful" or "if only the alchemy perks were more applicable to the way I play" or even just "I want my anime waifu as my companion, dang it". Modding those things into Skyrim Special Edition (which I'll refer to as "SE") is a cakewalk. SE is (at the time of writing) the most recently updated version of Skyrim available on PC. It includes all of the DLC from the original and, as such, it has the most updated mods out of all the PC versions. Because of this, if you hop over to Nexus Mods and open the homepage for Skyrim SE, you'll be greeted by countless mods that can be installed and set up with little to no effort. Certainly not all are worth your attention, but the sheer number of SE mods available means you can find a working mod to satisfy almost any change you'd like to make. That story is quite a bit different for VR.

To start, there's no good way to browse mods made specifically for VR because Skyrim VR and SE mods are all lumped into the SE category on Nexus Mods. Technically speaking, this makes sense; behind the scenes VR is actually just SE with some tweaks by Bethesda that make it function as a VR game. Because SE and VR share the same core game files behind this VR coat of paint, mods made for SE are — in theory at least — compatible with Skyrim VR. The reality though is that many SE mods aren't compatible with VR at all and not every SE mod that works on VR will work on the first try. This is in part because VR is based on a slightly older version of the game files than SE and hasn't been updated in some time. Certain content present in SE is missing completely from VR while some has been updated in SE but not in VR. Mods made for SE typically expect to be installed in the latest version of SE, but since the version used in VR is older you'll often have the game hang, crash, or generally misbehave the first time they are installed forcing you to either remove the mod or go dig up a compatibility patch. 

Mercifully, not *every* mod will wreak this havoc on your game and some of the most popular mods are compatible with VR right out of the box. I've personally had the most trouble with mods related to graphical upgrades to the game (improved lighting, ENB, re-worked water, etc.), but some functionally important mods like "Unofficial Skyrim Special Edition Patch" or "Ordinator" require their additional compatibility patch installed first to smooth over the problem spots caused by the mismatches between SE and VR. If you have experience modding Skyrim, whether that's through a tool like Vortex or by hand, you can no doubt get many of your favorite mods to work in VR with some coercion. If you have never modded Skyrim before and you want to try your hand at it, I would again point you to SE first as it is the more straightforward and forgiving option.


[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]

If all you want is to play vanilla, middle of the road, Skyrim-as-Todd-Howard-intended-but-this-time-in-VR, go right ahead and snag this game when it's in the $10-$15 range. Like all versions of Skyrim this is a moderately jank experience by default, but it does an adequate job of taking the highs and lows of plain Skyrim and putting them faithfully into VR. Similarly, if you have never played Skyrim before and are looking to dip your toe in, I would suggest you try out Skyrim Special Edition first since the addition of VR is really more of a novelty than a necessity.

If instead you are looking for the same Skyrim experience you know and love from previous editions of the game, preferably modded somewhere between a little and too much, [b]and[/b] you are willing to put in a great deal each of time, tears, and sweat to get there, this is the way to go. But even then, don’t pay more than about $15 for it.

133280447.review:
If you're a fan of RPG games, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR on PC Steam is definitely worth checking out. The game's captivating storyline, stunning graphics, and engaging combat mechanics make it an enjoyable experience for players.

But what really sets Skyrim VR apart is the vast modding community that has grown around the game. Mods like VRIK and HIGGS greatly enhance the gameplay experience, allowing players to customise their avatar and interact with the game's world in new and exciting ways.

VRIK adds a full-body avatar to the game, making combat mechanics feel more personal and intense. HIGGS, on the other hand, adds a physics engine that makes everything from objects to characters feel more realistic and responsive.

Overall, the modding community has truly turned Skyrim VR into an unforgettable adventure. While the game is great on its own, the added level of immersion and customisation makes it even better. If you're a fan of RPG games and are looking for a customizable gaming experience, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR on PC is definitely worth considering.

133040799.review:
[h1]Depending on how much time you invest in modding, this is either the best or worst way to experience Skyrim. [/h1]

[b]NO MOD :([/b]
The famously buggy intro is basicly all you need to know about vanilla Skyrim VR. The whole "youre finally awake" carriage affair remains unchanged and can be understood as an "make your players motionsick" speedrun tutorial, especially if you get lucky and the physics do weird Skyrim-stuff. After that you are two floating hands in a Skyrim that looks worse than your memories of flat-Skyrim.

[b]MOD :)[/b]
VRIK, HIGGS and PLANCK are mentioned in many reviws, Id like to add Mage VR to the list of essentials, casting spells with cool runes or gestures instead of having to equip them really helps with immersion. At the moment i use around 100 mods (of which most are just cool additions and not nessecary to enjoy the game) and it is the coolest shit i have ever seen. 

I completely stopped using fast travel because just beeing in this world wandering around is very enjoyable. Roleplaying is also a lot more fun if you "are" your Character because you can do silly little stuff the game wont notice but add a lot of details to your own personal lore. I always liked how litte storys just develop naturally while playing Skyrim and the fact that a lot of gameplay is more hands on in VR instead of just pressing a button and watching an animation really adds to this. There are just a lot more things that can happen or go wrong resulting in even more situational storytelling and I really like that.

[b]TLDR[/b]
Skyrim VR is a great game if you thought Skyrim was a great game. Sady its not a great VR game (maybe even a bad one). Luckily you can fix that with a few (or a lot of) mods :) Skyrim VR is still the same people, places, quests, etc. from ten years ago (at least without mods) so dont expect to be blown away by the "content". Skyrim VRs true strength lies inbetween these old content bits. Glue made out of vibes and immersion sticking everything together to create a wonderous and beautiful experience.

I have played flat Skyrim for hundreds of hours, growing a lot more detatched from it with the years. Skyrim VR feels like playing it for the first time again, all this wonder and exitement.

132437210.review:
TL:DR - If you have a VR setup it is well worth the money and makes Skyrim like a different game.

I was so impressed with Skyrim VR that I wrote a review after playing for 3 hours. Now that I have over 120 hours playing, and have played through twice, once as a stealth archer and once as a mage, I feel that an updated  review is required.

Firstly, I’m playing [i]almost[/i] a vanilla build, using two mods [i]“Easy Lockpicking and Pickpocketing”[/i] and [i]“Rally's Candlelight and Magelight Fix SE - VR”[/i] (Both from the Nexus) for the sake of playability and sanity. After 200 odd hours on Skyrim SE and 120 odd on Skyrim VR I have picked enough locks to know that I can do it and to not want to do it again, and as a mage, I use Magelight and the default blinds me.

Let's get into it. Skyrim always looked nice even if the vanilla experience is a bit dated now, but in VR it can be stunning, even with only the vanilla graphics. Being able to feel like you are actually there is awesome, and it is good enough that I avoided fast travel a fair bit, preferring to spend the time walking across the country. Sure, the snow and ice areas are pretty bland, but it is well worth the effort to walk around the more overgrown areas.

Even the indoor areas looked nice in VR and since you are able to set your height in game (I’m 6’4)  more than a few times I found myself ducking as I went through what appeared to be a pretty low doorway or tunnel.

Dark areas become really quite spooky in VR, far more so than when playing on a screen, and so the ambient sounds play a great deal more of a part than they usually do; I found myself paying close attention to what I could hear as an indication of where danger might approach from.

And so we come to combat. Generally my favourite build is a stealth archer, and this was enhanced by being able to actually place the arrow and pull the bow for myself while aiming. It's quick to get used to and there are various settings depending on how you get on with it and I can say that I have never enjoyed using the bow as much as I did in VR.

On occasion when needed, I also used swords etc. While personally I find the bow much more fun, it is immensely enjoyable to slap a bandit in the side of the head with a sword, an axe or a hammer. Again, much more so in VR and yes, I tried them all just because.

For the sake of experiencing as much as possible I also played through as a mage, spending a great deal of time enjoying throwing ice spikes and thunderbolts at anything that moved. Using both hands, one for defence and one for attack, feels very sensible in combat.

I played the main quest far enough to meet Delphine in Riverwood and then went off and played the Dragonborn and Dawnguard DLCs and all of the guilds (which don’t take that long) and I maintain that this is one of the most enjoyable games I have played in VR so far.

Sure, it's not HL:Alyx, and without adding a ton of mods it's still only Skyrim graphics, but after you’ve spent 10 minutes playing you don’t notice that any more, and you get the chance to enjoy the wonder of actually being in Tamriel, and of course if you have the hardware you can always spend a bit of time and add a bunch of mods to make it even better.

132162434.review:
(Mod installation tutorial at the end of this comment)

So you may have heard people talk about how bad the vanilla version of this game is.

Some people exaggerate about that.

The vanilla version of this is a decent experience, although not a very immersive one. But when you mod this game with certain mods, it is a very immersive experience.

It's a bit expensive though, wait for a sale or buy it if you have spare cash.

Here is a list of the mods I would recommend:

VRIK (Adds a player body)
HIGGS (Allows your hands to interact with objects)
PLANCK (You can grab NPCS and Weapons hit them instead of going through them)
Conduit (You can infuse weapons with your currently equipped spell)
SKSEVR (You NEED this for VRIK and HIGGS to work)

How do you install these you may ask?

Go to nexusmods.com and download Vortex, it is a mod handler that makes modding Skyrim Vr a LOT easier.
After that, install any other mods you want!

131240184.review:
Some people take the view one should not give Bethesda credit for what Skyrim, especially the VR version, becomes when modded with community content. Fair enough.
I'm considering the fact that this "game", regardless of its faults in the released state, manages to inspire so much passion in so many, enough to drive such talented and vibrant community to create what Skyrim VR is today.
One really needs to experience in VR the current state of Skyrim VR with right mods and visuals to appreciate what it is. Every minute of my Skyrim VR experience is a rollercoaster of the mundane (relaxing at an inn, watching NPCs go about their business, as I sip my ale), awe (at the vista), terror (try venturing out into the woods in the dark), intrigue, and laughter (ok, I laugh easily). No wonder I simply wander where my fancy takes me, simply enjoying and still discovering the world - I have zero intention of ever "finishing" the game.
As I start my 3rd year modding and "living" Skyrim VR, I have no problems giving Bethesda emphatic thumb-up for providing the platform for an incredible world for us to (literally) get lost in.

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR is an outstanding VR game that immerses players in the vast and beautiful world of Tamriel like never before. The game's graphics are top-notch, with detailed and colorful character models and environments that look great. The game's mechanics are smooth and intuitive, making it easy to get into the game and start playing right away. The game's AI is also highly advanced, providing a challenging and engaging experience that keeps players on their toes.

The game's character creation and development system is also very robust, allowing players to create unique and powerful characters that can evolve and grow as they progress through the game. The game's open-world is also massive and offers a lot to explore, from the different cities and towns to the different landscapes and environments.

The game's immersion level is one of its main strengths, playing this game in VR is an entirely new experience, the game's combat system is also highly realistic and allows players to use different weapons, shields, and magic to defeat enemies. The game's physics engine is also incredibly realistic, making the combat feel incredibly immersive and satisfying.

Overall, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR is an outstanding VR game that offers a unique and engaging gameplay experience. The game's character creation and development system is robust, and the game's open-world is massive and offers a lot to explore. The game's immersion level is outstanding, playing this game in VR is an entirely new experience, and the game's combat system is highly realistic and satisfying. It's a must-have for fans of open-world and RPG games and for anyone who wants to experience the game in a whole new way.

Disappointing cash-grab attempt to port Skyrim to VR. The game totally sucks without mods. Even with mods, the feel of combat and game world interaction doesn't come close to similar genre VR games like Blade and Sorcery. Until a better fantasy VR RPG comes out, I guess this is this best we have.

Cons
- Hands don't interact with environment (NPCs, items, anything)
- Missing body/arms means you can't easily see what you have equipped
- Melee combat feels much less intuitive. There's no clear indicator for when you're staggered, blocking is more cumbersome, and range is reduced for two handed weapons.
- the data graphics are even more apparent when you view the game from VR

Mixed
- With mods, things like magic and archery become much more fun - though melee still doesn't work well

Yes I recommend it when it is on sale and you mod it. Full price, absolutely not.

Matches the same level of interactivity and immersion as other leading VR titles like Alyx, once you introduce mods. The modding scene has really propelled this game to be something quite special when it comes to VR interactions and makes it a worthwhile experience. Due to this game being on the market for over a decade modding has been significantly streamlined to the point that there are now installers which will fully overhaul the game with all of the 'required' VR mods included making it a relatively stress free experience. With that said I would not recommend it at full price as it requires efforts on behalf of the customer in order to make it an enjoyable VR experience. Bethesda put forth the absolute bare minimum with the port of this title and slapped a full retail price on it. When it goes on sale, then I would absolutely say go for it. Marking this as a no due to too many caveats for straightforward recommendation.

129567291.review:
I'll say up-front that this is not a good VR game, in the state it comes. That being said, with a few mods, this becomes one of my favorite titles in VR. Without mods, I wouldn't bother. If you haven't modded Bethesda games before, this is where to start, because it's totally necessary to make the experience worthwhile. There are plenty of videos on it but I'd say the minimum are 3d sound, Vrik's player avatar, PLANCK and Higg's enhanced VR interaction. The list from there on depends on the person, but this is what I'd say is mandatory for it to feel like a real VR title and not a shoddy port.

The biggest positive of this release, mods or not, is the immersion of seeing Skyrim again in a VR perspective. Every big setpiece, every interesting location becomes amazing in VR. You'll find yourself looking around and generally looking up more, making memorable events like exploring the flourescent otherworld of Blackreach or the climb to High Hrothgar a much more profound experience. That's where the benefit of the base game in VR ends though. You'll need mods for it to feel like a VR release instead of an obvious port where the headset is the only benefit and your VR controllers are are poor stand-ins for a keyboard (the controls for which you can't seem to change, although I believe some mods might be around that remap the keys). 

Now for the negatives (even with what mods I have). Some of the controls are pretty bad. The shouting key is mapped to what would ordinarily be the dominant hand's "grab" button - very easy to accidentally hit. Save often because apart from random crashes, you will be accidentally fus-ro-dahing shopkeepers and villagers more than you will your enemies, pissing off numerous guards.  As for combat, regular melee combat isn't very fun in VR in my opinion. Some of the physics additions in PLANCK make weapons feel more weighty and realistic, but you're really just flailing your weapon at them - it's more affective to "bonk bonk bonk" hit them as fast as possible than pretend to swing a sword like a sword. Magic is much more satisfying as well has its own share of mods that add a lot of depth if desired. Beyond that, for me being able to aim the Dawnguard crossbow one-handed in VR is incredibly satisfying and archery itself is much more interesting in VR.

Overall, this is a terrible VR game without mods, and a great experience with mods. Skyrim is still Skyrim, for what it's worth (I personally don't feel the game or quests are anywhere nearly as memorable as Oblivion, and I probably wouldn't have played it again if it didn't get this VR release). That being said, being able to experience it from a VR perspective completely changes the game. You will notice details you hadn't before, discovering a room in a dungeon of slain explorers starts to actually look ominous and set some tension, and surprises like Dwarven spiders popping out of vents become borderline jumpscares. It's worth it, but only with a few mods that make a night-and-day difference.

129290506.review:
I'm going to preface this by saying that the community fixed this game for the developers, just like the flat screen skyrim. There are mods that fix everything that I've listed below and add even more to the game. However, this review is for the base game, not the hard work of the community. 

Alpha skyrim graphics, lots of stuttering and jitters, several bugs. Heck, the amount of bugs and glitchesI saw before I even left Helgen is astounding. My favorite was when (spoilers) ralof asks me to stay close as the dragon is attacking the town and then teleports somewhere else literally as soon as he finishes his sentence. He teleported a few times before and after that as well. 

There are no VR elements aside from the ability to freely swing your sword. You can pick things up, but they'll be floating next to your hand, just like the non vr game. Lockpicking is done with the analog sticks, just like the console controller. 

The visuals are horrendous, that includes EVERYTHING, especially textures except for maybe water in some places. The textures are especially bad. They look like they're from a ps2 game. 

Controller mapping on the quest 2 is also awful, makes no sense at all.

 The ONLY redeeming quality of the base vr game is that it's skyrim, literally everything about this is awful.

TL:DR: BAD. Literally everything bad. But very good with mods. Mods fix all, and make better. With mods game good. 

Merry Christmas/ Happy holidays.

128565614.review: Yeah, the price and need to mod it are bumps, but once you get past that, this game is in a small elite set of games that largely fulfilled the promise of VR for me and make it a must-have IMO.  Prior to VR, I recall buying a pair of 3D shutter glasses to use with nVidia's 3D Vision driver that allowed me to play Skyrim in 3D on a monitor. (yeah, the game is that old!).  I was mesmerized by the potential, but Alas!  It wasn't very playable for me, especially since I didn't have a monitor with the appropriate refresh rate.  Fortunately, VR fixed all that and transformed the game into the alternate universe it was really meant to be.  Personally, I prefer playing without the HIGGS or unofficial patch, but find the graphical upgrades essential--especially 4k textures if you play on a higher res headset (I use a Vive Pro 2).  Despite having well over 100 VR titiles in my library, including some pretty immersive ones, this title continually carries me farther into an alternate reality than any other.  I just wonder how much longer we'll need to wait for a proper successor?

If you like Skyrim, and like VR, get this. That being said, I mark it as not recommended because this is a somewhat half-assed VR port of an outdated version of Skyrim SE. I find it practically unplayable without mods, and it would be nothing if not for the vast modding community that holds up Skyrim in general. Frankly, it is deplorable that Bethesda would have you pay a further $60 dollars for this when the modding community does all of the heavy lifting for them, but it is what it is. No Man's Sky added VR in one of many free updates, and it actually feels like native VR support. Bethesda did $5 worth of work by slapping some VR hands into the game and gleefully ask for the full Triple-A price.

TL;DR: If you like Skyrim, buy it, mod it, and enjoy it, but always remember that Bethesda are scummy crooks who care more about a player's wallet than their own product.

127830555.review:
After playing Half-life Alyx several times I found this game on discount so thought I'd give it a go.

I installed the game and loaded it up with my VR headset. 
The Controls, The default settings did not work with my occulus hand grips, only 2 buttons worked and everything was using the trigger to move to the next option and not the A button like everything else does. After searching on google I discovered that it was set up for the Playstation beam controllers. Finally managed to get into the set up part of the game when you decide on what controls you want to use for movement - teleportation or walking.  An error occurred and the game went back to the menu screen and I couldn't find a way of getting back into the in-game configuration to select which bits I wanted to use. Back to google, navigated through the menu's and finally found it.
With HL Alyx I used the teleportation method of moment, was intuative, accurate and easy to use. With this game it looked like something out of the 1980's with this horrible curved coloured line to the spot you wanted to move to and it was only for real short distances. Settled for the walking movement.

Finally started the game where you travel down in this horse drawn carriage with other convicts. 
The talking between the characters was out of sync with their mouths and went on forever, there was no way to skip this so had to watch it all, your hands are bound so you cannot do anything with them.
After this section it started going with the people getting executed and the dragon appeared. 
Oh this looks good, the dragon looks great. Started following the adventure, got my hands cut free and started following the character around the building, 
I got handed my sword and started to practice but you could not move your hands to fight, you had to press a button. Your hands hover in front of you like you are playing "paper scissors stone" and that's the best they can do. You cannot cut with the sword you have to press a button. Completely defeats the idea of VR motion detecting hand grips. What is the point??

Kept positive and started running around the room checking out the chests and looting some items. Received several items of armor and got completely confused with the whole inventory system, It was just so confusing and difficult to use, trying to swap items without knowing the basic controls which took me 45 mins to set up in the first place I got completely annoyed with the game and had to take a break.

I had read somewhere that you could install mods to make the game better so looked them up and installed Skyrim Script Extender and Vortex. Opened up the game and there were some changes to the menu's but the controllers had defaulted to the beam type of system and the buttons on the screen did not match the controller buttons. After another 30 mins reading up on controller settings I managed to get things working again.
I installed the mod which improves the world graphics. Installed ok, started the game and was not impressed. Thought it might get better so decided to give it a chance.
Next, there was a mod that gives better hand control and another that shows your full body instead of just your hands. Nothing happened, this mod was at the top of the list, active, no conflicts all set to go. Loaded up the game and it was the same as before. I thought that maybe once we got past the horse/cart intro it would work as you could see your hands. Nothing happened.
I tried a few other mods which had dependencies on other mods for which I had the latest already installed but they kept coming up with incompatibily errors which I had to rectify but went round in circles installing/uninstallign them until I managed to get them all runing together but the end results were a total waste of time.

I first loaded this game up at 10am and by 3pm I had gotten nowhere with the mods, The game play was anoying and I lost total interest in the game and uninstalled it.
If I had paid £60 which was apparently the normal price I would have been very angry, but as I only had to pay £12.50 I didn't mind too much, 

I've been playing RPG's for years and know how they are played, I've played half-life alyx 5 times to completion so know how the controls should work. 

This game was so basic compared to what else is out there and would not recommend it to anyone. 

It could have been so much better if the so-called mods were integrated into the latest release with the option to turn them on/off depending on your hardware by default instead of having to learn through the community boards and google to try and find compatible modules. 
The menu system needs a total re-work as it's not easy to find anything. 
The in-game control system needs ripping out and starting from fresh with today's technology and not something from 10 years ago. It needs to be able to detect your devices and mould itself around them instead of you having to spend hours trying to figure them out.
It needs to start of basic and introduce things one at a time and give you reasons and methods on how to use the controls and the environment. 

If I didn't have any basic knowledge of games and was starting this as a new user I would be lost.
It's basically a 2D game converted to VR with basic controls and as you cannot see the keyboard and use that as a control method it's like playing a mobile phone game with oven-gloves on.

If they had integrated the half-life Alyx system of controls and graphics then this game could have been amazing. As it stands it was the biggest mistake of my life buying this game.

A whole day wasted.

127422494.review:
Disclaimer: I play a heavily modded (but pretty darn stable) version of this game.

There aren't enough good things I can say about SkyrimVR. Once you get the correct mods in place (VRIK, HIGGS, PLANCK, SpellwheelVR), use weather mods (I love Obsidian or Azurite), lighting mods (Lux, Lux Orbis, Lux Via), an ENB, and more, this game becomes the most fulfilling experience imaginable. I have clocked over 1400 hours in this game and do not see myself stopping.

It's difficult to explain exactly why this game does so well once it's fully modded. The controls, while not as simple as Half-Life Alyx or Blade and Sorcery, are extremely customizable. The world lends itself to exploration and wonderment. The quests you can add and the new places you can visit make this game incredibly replayable. Even simple quests you may have done a thousand times on desktop, such as delivering Farengar's frost salts or chopping wood for Hulda, take on a whole new life. And imagine being able to actually slap Nazeem. That alone is worth the price of this game! :D

Real life is stressful, and after a day of streaming, developing, or anything else, I need to unwind. This is the game I do it in. I can live a second life, walk from Lakeview Manor down to Riverwood, camp in the mountains of Eastmarch, or chill in the Winking Skeever in Solitude. I can hunt with Aela, smith with Adrianne, or get into trouble with Erik the Slayer. Or... I can download new places and followers and experience something new.

While it's true that you can do all of this on desktop, doing it in VR, when the game is modded properly, is a whole other experience. It doesn't matter how many monitors or surround sound headphones you use, nothing beats that first time you put on a headset and wake up to Ralof saying "Hey, you. You're finally awake." (Or use Skyrim Unbound and skip the cart ride entirely...).

If you have a headset and you love open world RPGs, you owe to yourself to get this game and mod it. I can even post my mod list here if it will help. ;-)

Welcome to your new obsession. <3

For the average gamer, out of the box this game is a mess with rudimentary VR tacked on.

I've actually put a lot of time in to modding Skyrim and Skyrim VR. The modding community for this game is amazing and if you're willing to chase that dragon, then you can potentially get to one of the best VR experiences there is.

Despite all the amazing modders putting so much love and attention in to this, it's a massively distributed effort makes coming from outside the company, and so things become fickle. This is especially true when some people in that modding community don't see eye to eye, modders or don't want to support the VR version of Skyrim, or Bethesda does something that breaks modding for VR.

It's definitely a good game - especially for those who like sorcery, swashbuckling medieval stuff in their games. The question is, are the graphics up to VR standards? I would have to say no - not if you are at all sensitive to graphics in VR - i.e. if low-res graphics make you feel queasy. You would then need mods.
I've tried a number of mods, and whilst many concerned with graphics do help a lot with the pukey feeling, most have failed at some point - often in dark scenes. I'm still trying to find one (or a collection of mods) that make me feel fine throughout.
If it weren't for that, it would be difficult to stop playing, despite the regular feeling of same-old, same-old that comes after the first few tasks/quests.  Some of the quests can also get a bit confusing for one reason or another - for this I have obtained two guides available on the internet - one the official strategy guide and the other is the IGN Wiki Guide PDF. I recommend getting these, but it will take you quite a while to read through them, so probably best to use them as reference books when you need or want to know more about a particular game method or quest. Reddit is also a very good place for advice and mod lists and guides.
With the help of these references, the game can be turned into something very enjoyable (pukiness excepted).

126668033.review:
Everyone says you have to mod this game, and that the game sucks without them. I ended up spending more time on setting up the mods and tweaking settings than actually playing the game, as i'm sure many others had. Even though I used a curated mod pack, it made the game crash frequently, and made it more buggier. All those mods really bloat the game, and made it take forever to load up. Lots of the mods are gimmicky and superfluous. Many of the gameplay mods made things more complicated than they needed to be, and some mods had no directions that could be found online on how to use them. Visual mods made the games aesthetic and art style inconsistent.

I went back to vanilla, and ended up loving the game. Crashes are rare, bugs less frequent, the game loads up in 2 seconds, which is great when you need to travel the map a lot when selling a large haul of treasure, or you need to reload after failed pickpocket attempts. The games visuals are good enough outdoors, and look outstanding inside dungeons. Everything works. Try the game in stock form and decide for yourself.

Aside from that, Skyrim is a game that works great in VR. It's easily one of the most immersive experiences that can be had. You put the headset on, and the hours just fly by.
