They did literally the bare minimum to port this to VR. 
In classic Bethesda fashion, they charge full price for an 11 year old game because the Fans keep it going with mods. Which is exactly what you need in order to enjoy Skyrim VR. 
"I think standard Skyrim VR is fine as it is" You say? Good for you sport. By the way, know that sled you've been playing on? Did you know you can take it to the top of a snowy hill and slide it down? You don't have to just sit on it in your back yard and pretend. It's going to blow your mind when you learn how much fun sledding can be. 

Back to Skyrim VR. 
If you're willing to learn how to use mods, Skyrim VR can be transformed into how it should have been on release. 
For example. Like role playing? Like building your character's face for 20 minutes? Well, sucks to be you because once you're done, you're a pair of floating hands with no body. 
"Then why did I just spend 20 minutes building a face?" Because it was easier to keep it in than to remove it. Character building in VR may as well be Race, Sex, Name, and then done for all the impact it has. 
You could argue cosmetics does nothing in regular Skyrim but it's fun to walk around in 3rd person and pretend your character lives in Skyrim. But in VR that won't happen. 

Also, why do you want VR Skyrim? 
"Well, to live in and interact with the world of course!" 
Okay, but you can't. Your virtual disembodied hands can't physically touch anything. Your sword phases through solid matter and enemies with no collision.

But with mods, although you'll not be able to see your own face, (at least not with the mods that I use) but you'll have a set of arms. You can walk into a bar and pick up a mug of ale, pretend to get drunk and throw that mug at the barkeep's head. If your companion gets stuck in the door, AGAIN! you can grab her by the hand and drag her aside, give her a smack on the ass and go about your day.

125680198.review:
This recommendation comes with some caveats. 

In truth, the [i]base[/i] version of Skyrim VR is borderline unplayable - even if you haven't played enough of regular skyrim to be bored of the vanilla content. The introductory cart ride bugs out in horrific fashion if your headset refresh rate is set higher than 90 hz and, even after fixing that issue, the game itself remains physically uncomfortable to play for even the most experienced of VR gamers.

What I'm recommending, then, is [i]modded[/i] Skyrim VR. But on the other hand, modding even non-VR skyrim yourself is an enormous hassle, isn't it? Days or even weeks spent choosing the mods for your perfect vision of the game, playtesting in tiny chunks to find issues that need resolving, then trying to find the source of those issues and resolve them in order to keep the game functional and playable. A whole lot of work just for the hope of having a good time at the end, many would agree. To say nothing of the extra headaches thrown into the mix when you introduce VR into the equation.

So, how is it that I manage to enjoy Skyrim VR? The answer is a little thing called Wabbajack. Not the ingame item (though there's little doubt as to the source of the name) but rather a piece of software you can easily find with a quick google search. 

Wabbajack is an automated modlist installer for skyrim (and a selection of other games with active modding communities) that takes the monumental task of modding the game and brings it down to a manageable size. Dedicated users cultivate their own personalized modlists - which are regularly updated, playtested and troubleshooted - for players to choose from and adopt as their own.

Make no mistake, installing a Wabbajack modlist will still be a bit of a chore. But it is nowhere near the insurmountable task it would be to achieve the same result by doing everything yourself. It is as simple as choosing a modlist from the Wabbajack gallery and following any directions the list comes with. Plus, if you happen to run into issues during the process, many modlists have their own dedicated discord servers full of people who might be able to help.

If you need help choosing a modlist for Skyrim VR in particular, lots of players recommend FUS as a starting point. Personally I play the more intensive Tahrovin modlist, and as a bonus I have found the Tahrovin discord community to be full of genuinely delightful people. I had my chosen modlist up and running within a handful of hours, and when I ran into issues they were quick to offer help.

As for how much fun the Tahrovin modlist is specifically, well, put it this way: at the time of writing this review, I've put more hours into it than Beat Saber.

125661598.review:
The FULL CREDIT for the positive rating on this review is due ONLY to the modding community. Namely Kvitekvist and his beyond amazing FUS modpack available with Wabbajack. Not only is he passionate, but he is dedicated to the point that he personally assists people in Discord with issues they run into during installation. For not one second do I give credit to Bethesda. They obviously only sought to cash in on "the VR experience" by re-re-re-re-releasing Skyrim VR in the state they did.

That being said if you buy the game do so with full knowledge that the vanilla experience barely scratches the surface of what you can achieve by modding. It requires a bit of patience and effort tech-wise but they're is a ton of support online for doing so.  If you put in the work, the reward you reap will be oh so well earned.

Take it from me. I am using the Cangar preset from the FUS modpack, and I played the tutorial realm for 7 hours. I just stepped through a crystal into Whierun and my mind is blown. I might live here. 

Also worth noting is the price. Do NOT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES BUY THIS PRODUCT AT FULL $59.99 PRICE. If you do so you deserve to be struck by a falling potted shrubbery. Buy on sale for less than $15, trust me there are plenty of places to (legally) get a steam code for $15 for this game.  

Tl;Dr
Unmodded the game is barely worth getting on sale for $15. Fully modded it is worth your weight in Exquisite Sapphire. But you can get it for about $15. Also, poor show Bethesda. Poor pooooor show.

125500654.review:
I wish I could mark a review as mixed instead of one of two sides because I [i]really[/i] want to recommend this game, I do, but this review is for the game, not my experience with it. There's a TL;DR at the bottom, but I encourage you to hear me out in full.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
The VR UX being better than FO4 doesn't justify the price in the slightest. If this was a $10-$20 add-on for Special Edition then it would be more than worth it and $25 to maybe $30 standalone would make the most sense if they [i]really[/i] wanted your money, but no, you pay full AAA price for the bare minimum of a VR experience whether you own every single other version of the game or not. I'm not exaggerating when I say it's the bare minimum; there's motion sickness settings, gameplay supports 6DOF with touch controllers, and a new main menu where you can walk around and adjust settings. That's it. Everything else is identical to SE, the worst offender being the UI. It's insulting that they believe VR makes up for the blatant laziness/cash grab attempt.

The biggest issue is the lack of interactivity. The whole point of VR is to truly [i]be[/i] in the world you've entered, but Skyrim VR does everything possible to go in the opposite direction. The Half-Life: Alyx floating hands aren't as charming when they serve as a deceptive illusion instead of a deliberate game design choice. "Grabbing" items still functions like the cursor in flat mode and the dated combat is made infinitely more apparent when you're physically swinging your giant warhammer into an unresponsive foe. The only thing they nailed was archery and magic (probably a happy accident from the 6DOF support), which leaves dedicated stamina or spellsword players (me) with the worst experience.
If all these glaring issues are so bad, why did I put as much time as I did into it, and why am I playing it immediately after posting this review?

[h1] The Good [/h1]
Mods. You already know this. Why it should've just been an SE add-on is one of the reasons it's so good. Since it's literally just Special Edition in VR, 99% of the Special Edition mods work no problem. Download the [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/about/vortex/]Vortex mod manager[/url]if you're a casual like me, download [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/23416]VRIK[/url]so you can actually see the dragon armor you worked so hard for, then download [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/43930]HIGGS[/url]and  [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/66025]PLANCK[/url]so the VR game you're playing plays like a VR game. [i]This[/i] is what the bare minimum should be, but unfortunately you've got some mods to set up.

Whether it's vanilla or modded, you can't deny the atmosphere. The trees of the Rift, the sound of a calm stream with the harmony of crickets in Riverwood, the night sky cutting through the mountainous vistas of the entire region, all of it is gorgeous in VR and is the most enlightened you can become when playing a video game. I climbed the tower of Faldar's Tooth and just sat and listened to the ambient music as I looked upon a setting sun nestled in the valley of two mountains, its reflection on the nearby lake. I'm surprised I remained mortal.

The melee combat is laughable, but everything else is sublime. The archery is exactly as VR archery should be. Aiming your Destruction magic at multiple foes at once will activate every dopamine receptor you have. Physically crouching to pickpocket or sneak attack someone will put the dumbest smile on your toaster-head goblin face.

I'm going to dedicate a paragraph to the dragons. Nothing will prepare you for how big they are, and [i]you're[/i] the one slaying them, not your avatar being controlled by some buttons. The music, the scale, even melee combat with a dragon makes you long for every chance you get to devour some souls. Peeking your head over cover only to see an enormous lizard incinerate your entire view with guttural noises will, dare I say, feel just as epic as it did in 2011.

[h1] TL;DR & Conclusion [/h1]
Skyrim VR gives me my most conflicting opinions I've ever felt. The vanilla gameplay experience for this price tag is borderline malicious. According to Steam I'm leaving a negative review, but because my playthrough is getting hard carried by mods I'm being completely honest when I say this is some of the most fun I've had playing a video game.

Get the game on sale for $12 and it'll be your best 12 dollar purchase in any possible timeline.

124192748.review:
I am a fan of Skyrim, but i am not a fan boy. That said Skyrim VR should have been the version that was released first. Yes, we all know, Skyrim has bugs, a lot of them and to get them all fixed, you need to spend a lot of time on modding the game. Yes, Skyrim has mod support, but if you are not willing to learn how to mod this game correctly, you can quickly have a very bad time with constant crashes or end up in state of the game where it becomes so unstable that you can't finish it. 

But once you learned how to mod the game, what to do with loose files, fix incompatibilities between mods, write your own patches, solve conflicts etc. mods can and will transform your experience with the game. It can change the game from a great game to something outstanding. The VR version is no different. 

And what comes on top of everything, is that you are now "in" in the game. You can become part of the story and it is darn immersive when you can bend a nose or two when you are asked if you go to the cloud district often. I can't answer the question if it is a good game. All i can answer in this instance is that it is Skyrim. Play it, enjoy it. I certainly do as i also do when i look under the hood.

If you are looking for an experience you can just boot up and get running in a stable manner, this isn't it.
You will need mods for this game. A lot of Mods, I recommend.

It has Havoc Physics Bugs that can be fixed with 2 lines of code in the Ini File, because BETHESDA Didn't care. It didn't recieve the content of the Aniiversary edition, because BETHESDA DIDN'T CARE.

BUT.

It can be the best version of Skyrim there is.
Most Skyrim Special edition mods work with this game (unless they concern the features of the Anniversary edition). Everything that is great about Skyrim (The world) is Amplified to 250%.
The combat is actually interesting. The Sounddesign, the adventure, everything just clicks.

If you have a VR and are willing to mod this game to Oblivion, buy it on sale. Boy is it not worth 60 Bucks. Oh and prepare for Jank, even heavily Modded.

123755919.review:
This review is incomplete, because so far I have only spent about 4 hours modding this game, not playing it.

First off, the base game is absolute trash in VR. You can only walk round (VR style), swing a sword, and use magic. Where it breaks down: You pick up items with the A button, not by gripping them. The menus are navigated by the controller, not pointing at options (afaik). So it's basically a controller-based game, but you're in VR.

So, I generally don't recommend it if you're not willing to spend hours and hours modding this.

---

That being said, this can be an extremely immersive and beautiful experience. With the CAVEAT that you might need to spend hours modding it and need to have a beast of a PC to have high quality graphics and a decent framerate.

Or just get the Ugly Skyrim mod (assuming it works) and play "The Elder Scrolls: RuneScape" in VR.

123382388.review:
Let me preface this by saying I 100% do not recommend playing this vanilla, and therefore if you're uncomfortable doing techy tweaky things, or just looking for a install-and-play experience, this is not the game for you.

If, however, you are okay with the concept of mods, I'm playing this using the "FUS" Wabbajack mod pack, and it is actually really amazing... but it's been an ongoing tweaking experience for me. Updating this mod, tweaking the config for that mod, adding a gesture bind, reading stuff that had no TL;DR, even looking at the source code of some of the mods on github (which is the total opposite of a TL;DR).

Also, you're gonna want your VR legs... not recommended for sensitive stomachs.

But all that aside, being able to walk around in a world full of quests and dangers... hearing a dragon roaring overhead and bricking yourself. It's next level VR. Crouching in the shadows, firing your bow at bandits, or standing there with your arms outstretched blasting fire from your hands at your foe. Grabbing a pickaxe and swinging it to mine ore.

It was 100% worth the effort of getting it working.

Using Oculus Quest 2 + Virtual Desktop + elite strap with spare battery pack for extra-long cable-free gaming sessions. So good.

 - As a modding platform, Bethesda has provided something amazing for a highly customised VR experience.
 - As its own un-modded game, it's extremely underwhelming, and may be unplayable depending on your VR setup.

I highly recommend this game. As long as you have a decent computer, it's a total blast to play. I really love the open world aspect of the game, and it only helps that I've never played the normal Elder Scrolls before. Super fun! The controls are a bit confusing at first, but after about an hour tops you should have the basics down. Only not is that you shouldn't play if you have issues with your PC crashing (you have to manually save it) and don't try to make very good progress on your first save. At least not until you've thoroughly pressed all the buttons on your controller, as well as all button combinations. This way you don't accidentally ride your horse off a cliff. (I learned that the hard way)

Lastly before I go, don't bother the ogres. You know you've found one when you have, and trust me. I learned that lesson the hard way too when I approached one on my first save with a shortsword and my cocky ego... I didn't see the sunrise.

122129024.review:
Ignore my playtime, I may, uh, have played it elsewhere.

Solid 1/10 game, Skyrim itself is somewhere between "meh" and "awful" depending on your tastes, but this just takes everything to a whole new level.
Zero effort has been put into this port, I won't bother listing them since it's already been talked to death by a million people.
Don't play this unmodded, it's an absolute travesty, this should've been free for people who own Anniversary or Special Edition, not $60.
As you can tell, it's a port of a port of a port of a port of the decade-old Skyrim, with VR stuff slapped on top, probably by a handful of interns at the studio, clacking away a little bit on their lunch breaks.

If you're really big into modding Elder Scrolls games, go follow some guides online, then mod this into an actually decent port, or even mod it into a great game, sure, but a game's moddability shouldn't save it in reviews unless it's a clear part of the base game, which it isn't.
Still, I paid like $10 for this, so my wallet isn't mad at me, but you're downright goofy in the goober if you buy this at full price.

122052069.review:
Would I recommend this game on its own? As just the vanilla experience that it is without any mods whatsoever? Absolutely not. If you cannot run this game with some quality mods then you should NOT get it. It's awful and lazy and it is frustrating to know it was, and still is, released at $60 even if this game does include all DLC.

That said, would I recommend this game if you have the proper PC to run it with some serious mods? Hell yes. Without a doubt, when this game is modded to what the game really should have been already, it is the BEST VR game on the market, to date. There is no other truly open-world VR game you can play, as of writing this review. It's all of Skyrim and all of its DLC locations for you to fully explore in VR. The size and scale of every building, creature and tree is incredible. And with the right lighting and texture overhaul mods, you will find yourself wanting to walk from place-to-place instead of fast traveling just to take it all in.

Go to Nexus Mods, use their Vortex loader, and get yourself, at the very least, the following mods to make this the best VR experience you can get.

-SKSE VR
-HIGGS
-PLANCK
-Paralax 2020 4K
-SMIM
-Realistic Lighting Overhaul
-Realistic Water TWO

Just those mods alone will give you the VR experience you're looking for when exploring Skyrim. The physical body. The ability to pick-up almost anything and manipulate it in VR space. The absolutely gorgeous nights. If you can run this game with good mods, like these, then you will really love playing Skyrim again. If you cannot, then do not.

In short.. Vanilla "Skyrim VR" sucks hard and should not be on your list. Modded "Skyrim VR" is the best VR game there is, right now.

121994793.review:
Recommended with the caveat that it's not a good VR experience out of the box, you [i] need [/i] mods. 

Without a combination of [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/23416] VRIK [/url], [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/43930] HIGGS [/url] & [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/66025] PLANCK [/url] you will feel like a ghost walking through the world who occasionally bonks things with a sword. With these three mods, you'll be much more than a floating pair of hands that can't touch anything. You can directly interact with objects and NPC's in the world, the thing that makes VR games convincing and fun in the first place. 

The scale of the world is truly impressive, it's fun to visit familiar locations and get a real sense of how large and detailed these places are. The 3D does put some of the visual flaws under a microscope though, you can't trick the eye with normal maps like you can in 2D. A lot of objects look flat to a degree I found distracting. Luckily this is essentially just the Special Edition so 99% of the mods released work on here. There are re-textures and high-poly versions of just about every asset in the game at this point.

Skyrim VR can be great but you'll have to put in time and effort on the Nexus to get it there. That's not going to be worth it for some.

121772690.review:
you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

There are some mods you need to make this a better experience.
First, install SKSE VR and always boot up the game with that.

Essential mods are: 
- HIGGS
- PLANCK
- VRIK
- Skyrim Special Edition Unnoficial Patch (Search in google for the last version compatible with Skyrim VR, the one on nexus doesn't work anymore for VR)
- Spell Wheel VR
- SprintJump VR
- Simple Realistic Archery VR
- Auto Sneak and Jump VR
- SKSEVR Perk extender (for some reason perk extender mods doesn't work without this one, I havent tried ordinator).
----------
If your game looks kind of blurry at first try the SuperSampling option in VR Performance putting it way up, this will make the resolution better but obviously take performance.

119674432.review:
After installing VIRK, HIGGS, PLANCK, and their dependencies, this game is one of the best I've ever played.  First, I strap on some 5 lb ankle weights (why in a second), then I start up VRocker and configure it (found on Steam and allows you to naturally move), then I start up the game through the sksevr file, and finally enter the game.  You can do all of this from inside the headset, by the way, using the virtual desktop (aside from the ankle weights).  Time from initial setup to being in the game takes less than five minutes for me at this point.

Tip: you'll want to copy the sksevr.exe file to your desktop (I prefer directly on the taskbar, as it's right there).  Then just start the virtual desktop from inside the headset, click on the .exe file, and you're in the game!

I also have several texture and weather mods installed: Onyx VR Weathers, HD Skyrim Overhaul, and Noble Skyrim.  Yeah, HDSO and NS overlap a lot, but it doesn't hurt to have them both and they make the game look fantastic and very real.  Seriously, the game looks like shit without texture mods installed to make it look like Skyrim SE.  For some reason, they decided to use Skyrim LE as the base for VR, and it looks really bad.

Now, the game.  Rule number one: Avoid close combat with spiders.  AVOID CLOSE COMBAT WITH SPIDERS.  They are horrifying in VR and always make me run in the opposite direction (literally with VRocker active).  Fortunately, if you're a decent shot with a bow (and you'll become one, trust me), they can be easily dispatched from a distance.  On the other hand, physical combat is really fun with VIRK, HIGGS, and PLANCK installed, and I find myself reaching for my sword more than my bow these days.  Encountering bandits on the road now feels like a genuine threat, especially at a low level.

With mods (and a few outside extras listed above), Skyrim VR is simply incredible.  If only I could import my Skyrim LE save file to it (never played Special Edition).

119406974.review:
Disclaimer: everything i am about to say below is due to a wonderful Reddit Mod guide you will find in the reviews (Link here: https://www.reddit.com/r/skyrimvr/comments/8riiqk/and_refined_my_texture_and_modding_guide_140/. )The game, by itself, is a totally broken heartless port to VR that the Devs should be ashamed of! Get your Nexus mods account updated because you are about to get tweeeeeaked!

This is absolutely incredible! The feeling of life in this game I was not expecting. The visuals were just something you cannot describe without seeing it. I have played Skyrim and all DLC countless times, and here i have already put 96 more hours into just the VR version. I anticipate many more. The immersion of sneaking (turn on real sneaking in VR options) and stealth backstabs/archery is just insane. My first cave i was sneaking up to a set of stairs. A skeleton was walking down them and I let loose my arrow. The skeleton fell apart and i could hear each bone tumbling down the stairs. I almost cried! It was so good! Its a million more moments like this where you feel so connected to the game in a way you had not known you were missing in the non VR game. 

Now that being said there are still some things... all the time you walk into a room and random items fly around like a poltergeist just got its first set of feels. Sometimes random doorways, and especially rotating gates in some dungeons, wont let you pass and you have to finger bang the thumb-pads to get past. Bridges sometimes do not let you land on them if you had to lower them into place. I did find a save and reload on that often fixed it, but it was still annoying. Once in a while you would hit a mob with an arrow and it would fly into the sky giant style. All of that stuff didnt subtract from the game enough to make me quit. 

Would i recommend you pay full price? I want to say no but with the mods it really is wonderful. I would pay it. But DEFINITELY get this on sale. Dont hesitate, just do it. And follow the guide. Some of it is outdated and the mods no longer available, but 90% of it is still there, and some of it is to your own taste anyway. 

Spend another couple hundred hours in Skyrim with me. You'll be glad you did.

118575746.review:
I know I’m extremely late to the party but I still felt the desire to write a short review about it.

So, I never played the original Skyrim or the SE. I always regretted that. I did try to play it about a year ago but by then I found the game not that interesting. I wasn’t impressed by the graphics either and for a game that you’d have to spend 100’s of hour in, I wasn’t feeling it at all.

Fast forward to today. Installed Skyrim VR and immediately was impressed by the immersion level and the feeling of actually being in a big open world. The controls were not very impressive but serviceable while the graphics looked a lot better than I remembered. Probably because VR games in general have pretty lousy graphics, I found the Skyrim graphics quite good.

Then I figured, why not mod Skyrim? Took me about a day to install a modpack (which was quite easy for even a novice like me, the downloads just took forever). Installed Wabbajack en got the FUS modist. Wow! Just wow! Graphics all of a sudden went from cool to fantastic and the gameplay… oh man, the gameplay. It actually feels like a proper VR game now. I can interact with stuf, see my body with the armor I’ve got equipped, use spell wheels, hear 3D sound, etc etc. This now has become one of the most immersive games I’ve ever played. At this point, I’m happy I didn’t play the original. Going in fresh is utterly magnificent.

After Half life Alyx, I found most other VR games rather boring (maybe with the exception of RE4 VR). I had my Quest 2 laying around for months with nothing I wanted to play. This holiday I bought a bunch of VR games, including Skyrim VR. Skyrim was the last game I tried. I knew I had to mod it if I wanted to best experience and the prospect of that was pretty daunting. Turns out it’s literally child’s play with modlists and tools like wabbajack. 

So yeah, I know this isn’t a typical review. It’s just me gushing about my experience. But, I just HAD to share that this game, modded, is fantastic if you like rpg’s. Last time I was so immersed in a game was when playing HL: Alyx. I recommend Skyrim to anyone with a decent PC and a VR headset. Non of the videos you’ll watch about Skyrim VR can really convey how it actually feels in VR. 

This is overall one of the greatest experiences I had playing any game, it’s THAT good! Go buy it!

118277069.review:
[h1]SKYRIM VR MODDED[/h1]
[b]Step 0: Trust the random online guy (me) for advice because he spent hours figuring out this. [/b]
[b]Step 1:[/b] Buy the game
[b]Step 2:[/b] Run the game Once without any mods (This is required for mods)
[b]Step 3:[/b] [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/about/vortex/] Download and install Vortex[/url] 
[b]Step 4:[/b] [url=https://next.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/collections/quwmrb?tab=about] Download the VR Mod List [/url]
[b]Step 5:[/b] Fix the VR Mod List
[b]1 -[/b] After Downloading all mods, [url=https://github.com/Odie/skyui-vr/releases] download "SkyUI" latest release and drag that to vortex for installation.[/url] - It should be named something like SkyUI.v1.2.1.7z (not the source codes)
[b]2 -[/b] Next Find and Remove [i](uninstall)[/i] [b]"Unofficial Skyrim Special Edition Patch"[/b] - causes the F*CKING GAME TO NOT RUN
[b]3 -[/b] [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/266/?tab=files&file_id=209150] Download older version of [b]"Unofficial Skyrim Special Edition Patch"[/b] [/url] - And install through drag a drop on vortex
[b]4 -[/b] Find and [u]disable[/u] [b]"FNIS PCEA2 - Player Exclusive Animations (dynamic) SE - FNIS PCEA2 7.2"[/b] 
[b]5 -[/b] Find and [u]disable[/u] [b]"BodySlide and Outfit Studio"[/b] - causes crashes when character creating
[b]6 -[/b] Find and [u]disable[/u] [b]"Sexy Skyrim SE Statues v2.1"[/b] - causes conflicts with other mods
[b]7 -[/b] Settle conflicts. It is pretty easy to do this. Just use common sense to figure out which mods go before and after.
[b]OPTIONAL 8 -[/b] Disable [b]"Realm of Lorkhan - No Shards Version (by Benjapo)"[/b] - this will allow the game to play its original story in the beginning. You will be floating in the cart for the first 2 min but after all the cinematics you are playing the actual story mode.
[b]Step 6:[/b] [u]Rate this review so other blokes can see it. You are welcome. [/u]

Game might still crash every now and then in the beginning but this will make it enjoyable to actually play. And trust me, DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME WITHOUT MODS. It sucks.

118273510.review:
Its Skyrim. In VR. But you are short-sighted and you forgot your glasses. Enjoy the barely visible landscape as you wander around as a pair of floating arms phasing through solid objects. And of course become motion sick as the decade old game can barely maintain its framerate becoming a choppy, vomit inducing mess.



Mods save this one by adding basic VR functionality like an actual body that interacts with the environment or being able to pick up weapons and objects and interact with/throw them. Differing returns on improving performance and fixing the insane blurring. Mods did not fix either of those problems for me. But considering the fact the game is running on a nearly identical version of (formerly) Special Edition there are tens of thousands of mods for you to play with.

Rich with content, doesn't come with contact lenses.

117881054.review:
Worst VR experience yet.

Even with mods, this game is such a technical chore to play, the bugs are relentless, even from the "essential" mods themselves. Using VRICK, HIGGS, and PLANCK, I ran into the following:

-Mod installation errors that you can apparently just ignore (for some reason the game/mod manager has a hard time telling the difference between sksevr and regular skse; a fourth essential mod that isn't mentioned you need for other mods to work)

-The horse carriage intro will be (hilariously) buggy AF and make you think you did something wrong. You didn't. It's just normal and nobody mentions it.

-Pressing Continue instead of "Load Game", causes all my controller buttons to unbind. It thinks I'm using a Vive controller maybe? Needs a restart to fix.

-The default controller binds objectively suck to begin with. Some buttons literally contradict each other as "select" will also mean "exit menu" in some cases.

-Even HIGGS' sheathe/equip weapon controls BARELY work and you'll fumble your controls in fights.

-Every other restart of sksevr_loader.exe doesn't actually launch the game, only fix is to reboot the friggin' PC.

It really is a chore to play all around. I only recommend it if you have the time and passion to do so.

117057675.review:
Well what can one say about SkyrimVR that has not already been said...

The base game is good for its time.  But when you add enough mods, it becomes freakin' amazing for today.  I have the luxury of a 3090 and a G2 headset and SVR suitably modded looks real enough to touch.

More mods expand the map.  There are expansion mods for SVR that are as big as whole titles from other publishers.  The community is amazing.  You can play SVR as a survival game, a stealth/theft game, a hardcore combat game, or enable a couple of cheats and just stroll around sight seeing (and the sights are worth it -- some of the most beautiful scenery and architecture in gaming).  There are many different character types, many different storylines, huge replay value.

SkyrimVR is not really a game, it's more of a hobby or a way of life.  It's a real-feeling place that you visit, a vacation from the real world, like a waking dream that you can step into whenever you want.  SkyrimVR is what VR promises:  another world.  It's fully open and fully modelled -- go off the paths, head into the bush, orienteer your way ad lib around an expansive, scenic landscape.  Until you hit the map boundaries there will be no limits, no "back sides" to things -- it's all modelled all the way down.

I have a lot of VR titles and I've enjoyed most of them, from casual toony sims to fairly sophisticated A-list games, but the one I never get tired of, never get bored with, always come back to... is SkyrimVR.  Give it a try if you seek immersion, gee-wow vistas, humblingly huge structures and spaces, atmosphere, occasional creeps and jump scares, elaborate combat, magical spells, a ridiculously complex lore, and quirky NPCs who are only too eager to tell you their life stories.

It's the title that would not die, and there are reasons for that.  SkyrimVR is the best single reason to buy a headset, and one of the most compelling demos you could ever show to a friend, to explain to them what VR can do.

What's cool is that with just a couple of essential mods, this becomes one of the most immersive and entertaining VR games I've ever played.

For example, I was able to grab some guy's leg and pull him from the horse carriage, and when he picked himself up from the ground, I grabbed him by the collar and bashed his face in before dumping the corpse in a gutter. Then I grabbed some guy's ass until he turned around and said "let's get something straight", and I winced in disgust when I heard these words being uttered out loud... Actually that last part didn't happen but it would probably be very easy to script it because you can totally grab everyone and everything, and they will get really angry at you if you'll keep trying to pick their noses.

But what's not cool about Skyrim VR is that, in their boundless greed, Bethesda used this as an opportunity to resell you Skyrim for the 75 billionth time at full price and they didn't even bother putting in any effort. It would remain one of the most awful VR ports if it wasn't for the modders, and the ONLY reason this has positive rating is thanks to the amazing work that those absolute legends have put in it for free. This really should've been a free VR graphics API instead of a standalone 60 dollar release, so even though it's great once you mod it, make sure to grab it only when it's at deep discount.

116613528.review:
Played only on an Oculus Quest 2 at the time of writing.  Your mileage may vary depending on your hardware.

Once again, Bethesda games' modding community proves itself to be better, more imaginative developers than the actual developers.  Combining the VRIK, HIGGS, and PLANCK mods (with honorable mentions of Conduit, Weapon Throw VR, and Spell Wheel VR) fundamentally revolutionizes the experience by letting your character and equipment physically interact with the world.  Seeing these mods demonstrated were what motivated me to finally take the plunge into VR.

Grab a potion and run to a dark corner before pocketing it.  Shake hands with a newly met NPC.  Grab someone's shoulder if they start to walk away before you're done talking to them.  Chuck a tankard at someone to start a bar fight.  Slit a bandit's throat and carry the body away over your shoulder before the others see something wrong.  Throw a battleaxe and behead Nazeem from across the street, then use his corpse as a shield from the arrows of disgruntled guards.  Suplex a dead dragon to add insult to injury.  Play golf with a warhammer and a chaurus egg.  These three mods make all of this possible and more, and it's embarrassing that Bethesda didn't develop this functionality on their own.

The only thing I don't like about this game is that we could've had this incredible gameplay experience four years sooner if this IP was in the hands of a more competent studio.  I don't even mind the fact that I've now bought Skyrim 2¼ times.

This is a poorly executed VR port for skyrim, which does not even work properly. 

Having to press buttons instead of actually grabbing things (with the index knuckles controllers might i add), the visible, rendered controllers ingame and the invisible body (just floating hands) completely breaks the immersion, which is... like the whole point of VR??
Smaller VR titles like blade and sorcery could manage a normal inventory and equipment system, like actally having to reach behind your back to grab your sword etc etc.

Here? Naaah, just press some buttons my guy, but we wont tell you which ones because we don't even give the smallest ammount of human feces what kind of controllers you use, we just put some default bindings on the screen for you, so good luck. Also dont be suprised if your weapon disappears mid-combat because for some god forsaken reason on the index controllers the equip/unequip command is: squeeze your controller for at least 3 seconds. Which you might do when you're bashing in some imperial bastards head with a hammer.

In its current state I cannot recommend this to anybody, you'll be better off playing skyrim v1.0, it's sadly ten times more fun than this poor excuse of a cashgrab.

It is a shame that the modding community has to carry the burden of this blasphemy that bethesda has brought upon this earth, and make it a bit more playable game.

116134767.review:
Stop telling the false story that "it will be the best VR game after mods". [b]It is not.[/b]
Skyrim VR in Vanilla is a totally unplayable digital junk so much so that it needs to be questioned if it qualifies to be a game; Skyrim VR with mods barely becomes an averagely playable game - but at what cost?

[b]First, you will have to spend hours, if not days, finding and downloading mods from different sources.[/b] You may save a little bit of life here if you modded the original Skyrim before, but modding the VR version adds even more frustration and confusion to the already exhausting chores. You need to filter out the mods that won't work in VR and those only [i]theoretically [/i]work but in fact infeasible due to VR limitations, and carefully assemble your curated mod list together only to hope that it runs within the narrow happy zone between minecraft graphics and burning your machine to ashes.

[b]Second, you will have to live with the stutters, screen tears and bugs that are not only annoying, but literally hazardous to your physical health. [/b]The very advantage of VR's immersion makes any glitches much more dangerous to overcome. There're too many mod glitches and performance issues that will transform your headset screen to powerpoint slides, a spinning tumble washer, or van gogh's gallery. You're likely to suffer symptoms from motion sickness to literally vision traumas.[b] Welcome to the real Cyberpunk 2077, where your game has a good potential to kill you.[/b]

Lastly, you're a master mechanist and craftsman of Skyrim mods, and you're immune to any form of vision and neural disorders - [b]congrats, you now can play your good old Skyrim... in VR[/b]. Admit it - there's nothing fancy or unique of Skyrim VR, aside from the VR itself. You play the same content (with much more clunky controls) and the enthusiasm quickly burns out after the initial VR freshness hype fades away.


Is a worth a try? Maybe if you enjoy VR games or basically enjoy the process of scrap engineering.
Is it worh $70, or even on sales? No. It has less quality than an average fan-made VR mod for other games and, being a player who only wants to pay for a fun game out of the box, you should probably invest your money and time elsewhere.

116040645.review:
Vanilla game review: Complete garbage. Not worth the money even 99% off. Shame on Bethesda who care so little about Skyrim fans that they continue to shovel a different flavor of the same sh** into their mouths rather than creating a long-overdue sequel in the Elder Scrolls series.

Modded game review: The best single player experience on VR.

If you buy this game, learn how to use NexusMods and Vortex. I currently have around 60 active mods going on this game because the mods that work on Skyrim Special Edition also work on Skyrim VR, for the most part. The result? Many unofficial bug fixes, NPC and player models are improved dramatically, many of the statis objects are complete re-textured in HD, the level-up system is re-worked, you can see your own player model looking down (which is not in vanilla Skyrim VR, mind you), NPCs idle and day-to-day activities are re-worked to be more immersive, more weapons are added, more armor is added, more enemies are added, spells are re-worked, nightime skies are HD and cycle between galxies and northern lights, daytime looks privy to Minecraft HD sun shaders, and so, so, so much more.

The reviews of this game are painfully bad on Steam, but with a little trail and error with modding, you can turn this into one of the coolest, immersive VR experiences out there. This is only thanks to the community of people who love the Elder Scrolls games enough to create so many mods that the game is practically unrecognizable compared to how Bethesda left it.

Buy this game on sale (usually for $20) when the next big sale comes around, install Vortex, watch a few tutorials, and have a blast. It is crazy to me that so many years later, Skyrim can still be a fun game.

Special thanks to the community for making this possible.

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR is a lot of fun, but quite a lazy port from the base game to VR. With no hand interactions and just simple controller I/O from the base game, one could wonder if this game could simply have been released as a DLC of the base game, instead of a whole new release. Mods are the saviour of this game though, as with them you can make it a true VR experience.
The Story is exactly the same as the base game, with no changes whatsoever. Some of the perspectives have changes, you can look around while interacting with characters, but that is about it.
The Gameplay receives the most changes. The inventory now is managed through a fly-in menu that changes position based on which way you are looking when it was opened. Weapons can be swung much quicker than they should be, magic is fun and really good with the destruction school, and bows are made much more manual, requiring the loading of arrows. Bows clearly received the most attention with the VR port, with magic receiving the least, as not much needed changing. Melee weapons are weird, as clearly some work was done but dual handed weapons are clearly much better than single handed, and can actually be swung at a similar rate to single handed.
Overall, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR is a fun port of Skyrim, but ultimately is a very lazy port. Mods can make it better, but essentially its the same Skyrim we know and love. It could have been so much more, or could have just been bundled as a DLC, but is overpriced in its current state.
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim VR gets a 6/10.

Hope you enjoyed my review, god bless you

115352414.review:
If anyone has wondered about if they should get Skyrim VR, i would not suggest it. The fact that the game is not built for VR is painfully obvious.

- Combat 

Melee is far worse than playing normally, your strikes have no strength in them, so combat consists of you just slashing at the foe while it slashes back at you. It just isn't fun at all. It lacks all the possibilities and potential that it being an VR game gives. Bethesda didn't even try.

- Movement 

Movment in vr feels extremely awkward and clumsy, in combat, you have to run after enemies, alike bowmen and wozards, normally not an issue, but because of the throughly unenjoyable chore that it is in VR, it is infuriating. The lack of buttons available, means that many actions are performed with the same button, which works about as well as you might imagine, it doesn't.

- Interaction with objects and the world

This is perhaps the only good side in playing this game in VR, and it isn't much either. the ability to look around by turning your head is nice and all, but it gets old very quickly, considering how much of an burden the gameplay otherwise is. Interacting with objects is, poor at best, even with some top mods available. Most of the time, when you try to grab an item from a shelf, and place it in your inventory, which is done by putting your hand behind your head, the detection fails and the item drops to the ground like an overglorified rock. INFURIATING. A feature that was supposed to improve gameplay, ends up infinitely worsening it.


- In conclusion

Skyrim in VR is not a game. it is a chore, unpleasant to play, that doesn't provide an experience that surpasses the base game, in any way. I have used several mods during my playtime, most designed to improve the experience, but this doesn't quite work out well, the base game just, is not fit for an enjoyable VR game.  1/5

114553610.review:
I play this with my occulus quest through virtual desktop and fairly powerful pc. I use an Xbox core carbon black controller. 

I've played previous elder Scrolls, going back to playing hundreds of hours of morrowind back in the day, by the time Skyrim came along I was burned out on the series and could never really properly get into it. As a consequence I never really played Skyrim properly no matter how many times I tried. I'm so glad I never played it properly now!

Since I got my Xbox controller, which as I understand it is the best for compatibility, I've not been able to stop playing this game. 

I've previously played Skyrim vr for a while but standing up just kills even after a few years and big increases in fitness since I play vr almost constantly.  

I've now come to understand that this is the way to do things. 
A game like this that demands hundreds of hours can't be played standing up, and motion controllers while sitting down feels restrictive. A controller using head tracking for aim while fully immersed in the world of Skyrim is just so amazing.

As I understand it the reason this can be played using a pad is that they developed the PlayStation version and they put in controller support. The huge shame is that more vr games can't be played like this because I've not been so addicted to a game in a long time and everyone I show is amazed. Id love to play fallout vr like this too but it so far very few understand how perfect this control method for vr is.

114461496.review:
Unmodded Skyrim VR is a lazy, borderline unplayable cash grab. $80 is an unthinkable price for any VR title, let alone a port of a game that has been out for 11 years. So why am I recommending it? Because like every Bethesda game, mods solve all of its problems. 

Modded Skyrim VR is the most immersive and interactive VR experience I've had so far. It's a full AAA title with hundreds of hours of content, and while Skyrim was an ugly game even by 2011 standards it looks quite nice compared to most VR titles. HIGGS, VRIK, 3D Sound; various texture, ENBs and static mesh improvement mods serve to finish the job Bethesda started and turn Skyrim into a VR title worth playing. This is technically the Skyrim Special Edition, so you also have access to six years of user generated content. 

Skyrim on its original release was a disappointment for me. It felt watered down and shallow compared to its predecessors. But replaying it in VR with all these mods has given me a new appreciation for the game. Actually being there, in the room, face to face with the characters is a completely different experience than just staring at them on a screen. You find yourself roleplaying more - crossing your arms during a conversation, reaching out to "grab" an item an NPC hands you, sitting on chairs, eating food etc. 

In conclusion, do NOT buy this game unless it's on sale (don't pay any more than $30 for this) and you're willing to put in the effort to heavily mod it. Otherwise you're just throwing away your money. But if you work for it, you'll walk away with one of the best VR experiences you've ever had.

Of course, the mods are evolving all the time as well. 

The Skyrim VR (with mods) is also the best way to play skyrim by far.  The whole experience is different, and the appreciation for the world increases a ton in VR.

114258190.review: (Modded) The incredible VR inmersion + dated gameplay and dialogues yields a purgatory where everyone and everything is somewhat real until they glitch. And you believe and cease to do so often it is maddening. And terrible dialogues, ridiculous scripted loops from characters when rendered so realistic feels at best absurd, at worst, existentially dreadful. How long has that orc being seating there alone in the dark table of fort dawn talking to no one? Probably years, never really eating anything, but unable to leave, muttering to himself something that has no meaning. Should I free him? Should I leave him be? Does he nows he is not free? Does he care?.... Anyways, it is like Westworld out there. you can literally do anything to anyone and they wont remember, but every now a them a glimpse of recognition in their eyes will haunt you, reminding you of what have you done. And you might get uncomfortable...at least until the game resets itself.

114211866.review:
It's Skyrim. What else is there to say? After 11 years anything that I could ever say about this game has already been said. 
But to chip in my dime, Skyrim still has a good amount of content in side quests and explorable areas, even if the main story isn't exactly.. [i] all there [/i].
The game's not really worth the asking price, since they just did the bare minimum for making Skyrim into a VR game, the combat's shoddy, the graphics are shitty, and the performance is unoptimized.
At least the modding community is amazing, the modders, who at this point probably need pain medication due to carrying the entire game on their backs for so long, have been working for a while to make this game beautiful, add the mechanics to it that it really deserves and to optimize the game.

All in all, [b] wait for a sale [/b], and [b] make sure your computer is good enough to run ~50+ mods [/b]!

After about a month, stubborn me re-installed and tried again.  After another 2 days I appear to have a stable copy going. ----------------

Negative, so much that I just did a rage un-install.

Let me back up, I played the original to death on the Xbox.  I played SE and AE on PC, with a million mods running.  I even deleted it a couple times, because it got old but there's nothing like it.  I even played it in Spanish and German to help my language skills.

I just got an Index, and this was the first game I wanted to play.  I spent three days trying to get it to work the way I wanted.  I had the main mods installed.  The dealbreakers were the Survival Mode and the Creation Club.  

Basically, AE has many cool creation club mods.  The survival mode is awesome.  I wanted those to work.  Survival is a non-starter, I downloaded lesser nexusmods versions.  Ok, I can live with that.  I spent 1.5 days following an arduous process to try and get my creation club DLC to work, which in theory it can, and I gave up.  And I got so mad I deleted everything to do with Skyrim from my computer, so I can never try again.  I've gotten enough enjoyment out of this game.

Actual review from the 50 minutes I played, I started off impressed, the scale and the VR are awe-inspiring.  If only I could get it to work like I wanted... there are better, modern games to waste my time on.

The first thing Magellen did when reaching the New World, was burn all the ships.  Thus I deleted all my Skyrim PC files, because even today I was thinking maybe I coulda zigged instead of zagged and gotten it working. 

Play AE or something else on VR.

113995619.review:
So, I have to preface this review with one thing: without mods, this is not worth buying, especially not at $60. I got this game at $15 on sale with the full intent on modding it. This is because the only thing you actually get with the vanilla game is standard male nord no customization in a still very buggy Skyrim mess. Now onto my review with mods.

With mods, this game is more than salvagable. I am talking character creation, visible body, being able to physically grab things, weapon throwing, etc. Most mods for Skyrim SE are compatible with this, either by default or with mod patches. Weapon play feels great other than bows which still suffer from odd controls with or without mods.

Now, I know most people would probably say that rating a game based on a non-vanilla experience is wrong, but I don't feel like this game should be passed on if you have the patience to mod and troubleshoot, I just don't believe the game is anywhere near worth full price. If you can, try to get this game on a QuakeCon sale when it is 50%+ off.

113724482.review:
I don't recommend the base game because the base game sucks. It just doesn't have the features needed for a VR port and games like Pavlov and Blades and Sorcery beat the game in every way. However, Skyrim literally has the most talented modding community I've seen. Mods like VRIK, HIGGS, PLANCK, Spell Wheel VR and even Mage VR carry this port hard. They all give Skyrim VR the features needed to be such a fantastic VR game as it should because in all honesty, Skyrim and VR would work so well together if Bethesda put more effort into the port and these mods show it. Despite what it says on my profile, I've put in nearly 400 hours into this game purely because of the mods, that's how transcendant of an experience it can possible be. So, if you're considering buying this game, make sure to mod it to enjoy it at its fullest.

TLDR: If you want to play Skyrim VR, Use VRIK, HIGGS and PLANCK. Everything else is pretty much secondary, but these mods are very essential to making the game oh so good!

113088795.review:
Skryim VR brings the popular massive open-world action RPG to virtual reality. It almost feels like you're living Skyrim instead of just playing it. I haven't even modded this yet and it's still pretty amazing. However, there are many recommended quality-of-life and eye-candy mods. 

You can find recommended tweaks/mods/etc. here:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qbh7GE30xLyso7MA6u3xpNJNdL5r2V2WP8SjZ4VpHLQ

Manual movement is best for immersion and roleplaying but after about an hour of standing in manual mode, I nearly blew chunks, so I switched to sitting. (if you play sitting, adjust your player height in game settings) I have a fairly strong constitution and I still feel a little queasy. According to people who actually suffer from motion sickness or vertigo, they couldn't even take 10 minutes in manual mode, they could play longer in teleport mode but still got sick. Taking a Benadryl or a supplement may help. There is also a SteamVR add-on for supported VR games called Natural Locomotion.

112771663.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

111343345.review:
It is fine, but for me, what this really game really showed me was it is not as important to have an immersive VR view and to be able to look around as it is to make the game mechanics and controls work well for VR and make you feel like you are using your body as much as possible to make it feel like you are in the game.

For example, the combat rules are the same as the non-vr version and parrying and attacking are done like flag signals so parrying is a position you hold your weapon. You do not perfrom a good deflection or counter blow specific to the enemy's action and your weapon  swing and the collision with your opponent has little to no impact on damage. Also your shield only blocks arrows when held in a specific position so that you cannot block attacks and arrows coming from the side and you must turn first which means you can only defend against the guy in front of you.

I played this game a bit and mostly just toyed around before switching to other smaller VR games with less content and "inferior", but maybe more functional  graphics that are simply more fun to actually play.

As I write this now there is an increasing number of "real" VR games in the RPG style that better show what VR can do and how much fun it can be.

Still giving it a thumbs up because it does show VR can work well with a full scale RPG setting and it has all the AAA stuff you can't get from a true VR game so it is a good transition in the early days of VR.

111319334.review:
Pros: It was the first time I was scared of fighting wolves, bow and arrow looks really cool, casting spells looks nice but it's really weird since it wil not go from where your palms are pointing but actually where your arms are :/
Cons: The game without mods is just impossible, with mods is more possible to play, but still most textures will be 2d, which look awful in VR, the game offers no keybind modification out of the box, so it's a STRUGGLE to learn how to play it. It's difficult to know when you're crouching (even though you're doing it in real life, most times I had to lay on the floor).
The game is nice overall, but not when you just get regular skyrim and port it to VR with not many tweaks, specially the price it is :/

111285472.review:
I give this a recommendation with two GIGANTIC caveats.

Caveat the first: This game NEEDS mods...
You're looking probably at least 5+ just to meet the barest of bones QoL to really make the game shine. Like having an actual avatar instead of being a set of disembodied hands or substantively interacting with the environment. Once you get through those it really starts to shine. It doesn't seem like there is a huge difference between looking at a floating hand vs being able to see your arm but there really is.

Caveat the second: The Price 
IMHO this game is NOT worth the asking MSRP of $60, especially with all the tinkering that it needs under the hood. If you are going to buy it my advice is to buy it on sale. 

At the time of this writing I think I've spent about as much time fighting with mods as I have playing the game, but I think I've finally hit a decent balance and can stop playing the introduction to the game on loop while trying to make sure things aren't going to explode. 

There are a lot of other high fantasy VR games out there but from what I have seen of most of them at best they look like highly polished tech demos. While the Elder Scrolls VR Port certainly shows it's age it's the most complete world. It probably doesn't hurt that I've spent years avoiding the franchise so the experience is also completely new to me.

Even if I feel the need to tap on the Caveat sign one final time.

110854979.review:
A mostly barebones VR version of Skyrim that was quickly abandoned by the developers.

I'm hesitant to mark this as a positive review, as the game out of the box is just not worth it. You need mods to make it worthwhile.

The mechanics of the game are largely unchanged from the regular edition of Skyrim, with the addition of 3D projected menus and motion controller supported combat. Everything else remains mostly unchanged, including menu controls and minigames and all the tedium that brings.
The VR version was quickly abandoned after release, ceasing official support and updates. As such the engine the VR version is running on has lagged several years behind and is missing many new features that have since become exclusive to Skyrim: Special Edition, such as the Creation Club, along with the [b]ESL[/b] (light) flag for plugins. This means the VR version has a hard cap of [i]255[/i] plugins activated at a time, severely limiting how many mods you can have installed at once.


The only reason I'm leaving this as a positive review is because I find myself genuinely enjoying playing in VR with mods more than the flat-screen version (barring physical and technical limitations), the game feels so much more immersive and engrossing to play in VR.

Something as simple as being able to physically grab and pick up something in your hand, or wielding two-handed weapons with both hands (vanilla you use two-handed weapons with one hand) is missing from the vanilla experience and only accomplished through mods. ([url=https://www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/43930]HIGGS[/url])


I won't go into specifics about what mods to install, there are many guides and modlists available that can assist with this.

The Game itself: 10/10
It's a classic, pumped well over 1000 hours into it.

The VR Port of this 0/10.
You literally cannot even get passed the introduction cutscene 99% of the time because of how horribly ported it is. 110525751.review:
I didn't spend a lot of time playing the original Skyrim or Skyrim SE, but I can't get enough of Skyrim VR. (My hours played don't show correctly because I'm playing with mods).

The stock game is playable in VR, but you can significantly improve the experience with a good set of mods. I used Wabbajack to install "The Ulitimate VR Essentials List". It consists of around 500 mods that improve nearly every aspect of gameplay. It's still the Skyrim you know and love, but so completely immersive that time ceases to have any meaning.

110348032.review:
Uhh it's pretty good I guess.

Modding community has really kept this thing going. Mods for everything.
Mods such as VRIK and Higgs really add to the VR interaction. There's a throwing weapon mod but I enjoy the VR archery alone.
You want gambling mini games? done. You want random brawls and other expanded radiant stuff to occur? check. You want a pit fighter guild like Oblivion? there's that too. You want to do a side quest for nearly any NPC in the game to gain their favor? check. Additional storylines/quests or mods that expand the official questlines? There's that too. You want seasonal trees and foliage? Someone just built the framework in 2022.

One negative thing is there is still a hard cap on ESP/ESLs for VR at 256, so be wary. Or if you're good at combining plugins, then you should be fine.

First you need to turn off the default teleportation-style movement. Then you need to mod the crap out of it; download Vortex, get the unofficial patches, install VRIK, HIGGS, SKSEVR and SkyUI. Maybe Dragonborn Speaks Naturally too if you want to get really immersive. (It is genuinely a crime that Bethesda got lazy all this stuff has been left to modders, but it is how it is)

Do these things and you will have one, if not the, greatest VR gaming experience in the world. So good it ruins other games for you. I don't know how I can ever go back to a keyboard/mouse or controller setup after playing this!
